choices.text: Skin sensation testing

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient comes to the clinic complaining of a hypopigmented scaly patch on his upper back as shown in the picture below, that has been present for the past 3 months. He denies any associated itching, pain, or other symptoms. On physical examination, the patch is non-tender, and has well-defined borders. There are no similar lesions elsewhere on his body. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. KOH mount

 

Tinea/Pityriasis versicolor

 

Caused by Malassezia furfur (Pityrosporum ovale).

 

Clinical features:

  • Multiple, small, scaly, hypopigmented macules develop insidiously over the skin of chest and back in young adults.
  • Macules start around the hair follicles and merge gradually with each other to form large areas.

Diagnosis:

  • Examination of scales in 10% KOH - shows Spaghetti and meatball appearance
  • Wood's lamp examination: Yellow fluorescence.
  • Skin surface biopsy

Treatment:

  • Griseofulvin is not effective
  • Itraconazole for systemic therapy.
  • Ketoconazole, Clotrimazole, miconazole, econazole, selenium disulfide and sodium thiosulfate for local application

questions.text: Which of the following poison is not correctly paired with its antidotes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Warfarin – Vitamin A

 

In Warfarin toxicity, Vitamin K is indicated for its management (and not Vitamin A).

 

For emergent reversal of Warfarin toxicity, Prothrombin complex concentrates > Fresh Frozen Plasma are indicated.

 

All other options are correctly paired.

choices.text: Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

questions.text: A woman is scheduled to undergo a laparoscopic hysterectomy and seeks information about its potential drawbacks from the surgeon. What are the disadvantages of laparoscopic surgery compared to open surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Not knowing the extent of thermal burns

 

The disadvantage of laparoscopic over open surgery is not knowing the extent of the thermal burns.

 

The advantages of laparoscopic over open surgery are as follows:

  1. Less postoperative pain
  2. Less blood loss
  3. Cosmetically better
  4. Earlier recovery and shorter postoperative stay at the hospital

questions.text: During 2009 pandemic, which strain of influenza virus was responsible for the widespread outbreak affecting populations worldwide?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. H1N1

 

Recent influenza pandemic occurred in 2009 due to the emergence of a novel H1N1 influenza A virus.

 

Past influenza pandemics:

  • 1968 pandemic due to H3N2 virus.
  • 1957-58 pandemic due to H2N2 virus.
  • 1918 pandemic due to H1N1 virus.

questions.text: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by the egg in stool as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Trichuris trichiura

 

The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

 

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

  • ﻿﻿Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colourless.
  • ﻿﻿They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss.
  • In heavy infections of 200 adult worms or more (trichuriasis dysentery syndrome), the worms are in the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhea with profuse mucus, abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, and rectal prolapse. On examination, clubbing may be present. Blood investigations may show moderate eosinophilia.
  • Chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Around 0.005 ml of blood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day per worm.
  • Treatment is mebendazole or albendazole.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the clinic with a non-healing ulcer below the left eyelid that has been present for several months, as shown below. He reports occasional bleeding from the ulcer, especially when he accidentally scratches it. On examination, the ulcer is pearly in appearance with a rolled border, and there are visible telangiectasias on the surface. The lesion measures approximately 1 cm in diameter. The remainder of his examination is unremarkable, and he has no other health concerns. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Basal cell carcinoma

 

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is a slow-growing epithelial malignancy originating from the basal layer of the epidermis and related appendages.

 

Salient feature:

 

Extremely rare to metastasize (1:35,000), but can be locally invasive and destructive.

 

Most common malignancy in humans worldwide, constituting about 80% of newly diagnosed malignancies in the U.S.

 

Main risk factor:

 

Excessive UV exposure. BCC is more linked to intermittent recreational sun exposure than cumulative UV dose.

 

Mutations:

 

Common mutations include those in TP53 and other cell-cycle control genes.

 

Gross:

  • Clinically, it's distinguished by its nodular, pearly appearance with telangiectasia.
  • May present with a raised, rolled border, central ulceration, and itchiness.
  • Pigmented BCC has benign melanocytes, giving it a black appearance.

Microscopy:

  • BCC showcases nests of dark basaloid cells with oval nuclei. They often demonstrate a palisading border and resemble the skin's basal layer.
  • Histologically, tumor cells are similar to the basal cell layer of the epidermis and arise from the epidermis or follicular epithelium. They don't appear on mucosal surfaces, with cells at the tumour’s periphery often palisading.

Management:

 

Wide local excision with continuous histological examination for margin clearance.

questions.text: The test kit shown in the image below works on the principle of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Immunochromatography

  • The above image shows a HbsAg card test kit which works on the principle of immunochromatography.
  • The immunochromatographic membrane is used for antigen detection, while a nitrocellulose membrane is used to absorb the antigen from a specimen.
  • A coloured reaction appears directly on the membrane with the sequential addition of conjugate followed by the substrate.
  • Advantage → Rapid and include a built-in internal control.

questions.text: What determines the fate of the Mullerian duct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Y chromosome

 

The fate of the Mullerian duct is determined by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome as follows:

  • The SRY gene (Sex-determining Region of the Y chromosome) produces testis-determining factor which converts the bipotential gonads to develop into testis.
  • The Sertoli cells of the testis secrete Anti-Mullerian Hormone (AMH) that helps in regression of the Mullerian ducts (that forms the female internal genitalia).
  • In absence of SRY gene, the WNT4 gene (Chr. 1) helps the Mullerian ducts to grow.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl from Bihar presented with pain in the RUQ, lump in the abdomen. Investigation revealed conjugated hyper-bilirubinemia. USG abdomen showed dilated CBD of 6 mm. What will be your next investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. MRCP

 

The above clinical scenario is that of a choledochal cyst. 

  • MRCP is the IOC for choledochal cyst.
  • It can be classified via Todani classification.
  • Choledochal cysts are congenital dilatations of the intra- and/ or extrahepatic biliary system.

Presentation:

  • Patients may present at any age with jaundice, fever, abdominal pain and a right upper quadrant mass on examination; 60% of cases are diagnosed before the age of 10 years.
  • Pancreatitis is not an infrequent presentation in adults.
  • Patients with choledochal cysts have an increased risk of developing cholangiocarcinoma. 

MRCP will reveal the anatomy, in particular, the relationship between the lower end of the bile duct and the pancreatic duct.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with painful swelling over his calf. He was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis & was started on a new drug. After 2 days, he presented with the given finding. Which of the following drugs is implicated in causing the given condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Warfarin

 

The patient presenting with gangrene of the digits 2 days after starting therapy for Deep Vein Thrombosis is suggestive of Purple Toe Syndrome caused by Warfarin.

 

Warfarin is an anticoagulant that acts as a Vitamin K antagonist.

 

Significance of Vitamin K:

      1.  
  1. Vitamin K is required for the Gamma Carboxylation of Glutamic Acid Residues of clotting factors 2, 7, 9 and 10 in order to activate them. In this process, Vitamin K is itself inactivated. This inactivated form is Vitamin K Epoxide. To convert this inactive epoxide into active Vitamin K Hydroquinone, we need Vitamin K Epoxide reductase. This enzyme is inhibited by Warfarin.
  2. Vitamin K can also activate some of the anticlotting factors like Protein C and Protein S. If anticlotting factors finish first, then clotting will increase, this leads to hypercoagulation, which can result in dermal vascular necrosis and purple toe syndrome.
    • It is an early side effect, that appears 2 days after initiation of Warfarin therapy. It is not seen in normal people; it is usually seen in people with genetic deficiency of Protein C.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the nephrology clinic for a routine check-up of his renal function. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes, which are known risk factors for kidney disease. The doctor decides to assess his renal clearance of specific substances to monitor his kidney function. Identify the correctly matched pair of substances with their renal clearance from the graph given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH

 

The correctly matched pair of substances and their renal clearance is option B.

 

 

The concentration of the substance changes as it passes through the tubules. Removing the substance from the filtrate is k/a tubular reabsorption and adding more of the substance to the filtrate is k/a tubular secretion.

 

Amount of the substance finally excreted = Amount Filtered + Secreted - Reabsorbed

choices.text: CRP has no association with risk of MI/stroke
Increase in CRP leads to increased risk of MI/Stroke
Increase in CRP decreases the risk of MI/stroke
In quintile 1, there is no risk of MI/stroke

questions.text: A researcher investigated the relationship between C-reactive protein (CRP) values and the risk of myocardial infarction (MI) or stroke. The study group was divided into quintiles, and the table below displays the results. Based on the findings, which statement is true regarding the association between CRP values and the risk of myocardial infarction/stroke?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Increase in CRP leads to increased risk of MI/Strode  

  • From the study results, option B is the true statement i.e.; an increase in the CRP increases the risk of myocardial infarction/stroke.
  • Relative risk (RR)/risk ratio is the ratio of the incidence of the disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed.
  • It is a direct measure of the strength of the association between suspected cause and effect. The larger the R, the greater the strength of the association between the suspected factor and disease. As there is an increase in the RR with increasing CRP levels, the risk of an MI/stroke also increases with elevated CRP levels.
    • R = 1 indicates no association.
    • RR > 1 indicates a positive association.
    • RR of 2 or higher indicates a >/=100% increase in risk.

Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a + b)]/ c/(c + d)]; where,

 

 

In the question, the table shows an increase in relative risk with an increase in CRP values. This thereby indicates that an increase in the CP values increases the risk of myocardial infarction/stroke.

 

Note:

  • Relative risk provides information on the increase or decrease in the likelihood of a condition based on exposure. It does not provide the absolute risk of the event occurring. The last option states that "In quintile 1 there is no risk of Mi/stroke".
  • Even though the relative risk is 1 in the first quintile, it does not specify that there is no absolute risk for the occurrence of MI/stroke. So, the last option can be excluded.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female is currently being assessed for multiple instances of recurrent pregnancy losses. Upon performing an ultrasound, there is a suspicion of a Mullerian anomaly. What would be the most effective method to verify this suspicion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hysteroscopy + laparoscopy

 

Mullerian anomalies are diagnosed by non-invasive methods like:

  • Hysterosalpingogram
  • Sonosalpingogram/ Sonosalpingography
  • Ultrasound
  • 3D-USG
  • MRI (Investigation of Choice)

However, a hysteroscopy-laparoscopy is the best invasive way to diagnose Mullerian anomalies (and can be treated at the same sitting in certain situations like a septate uterus).

choices.text: It inhibits Dihydrofolate reductase
It inhibits AICAR transformylase
It inhibits methionine synthase
It inhibits Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex

questions.text: A 35-year-old female has presented to the OPD with the following hand findings. She is started on Methotrexate for the same. Which of the following statements describe the correct mechanism of action of this drug in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It inhibits AICAR transformylase

 

The given image findings are suggestive of Rheumatoid arthritis, for which methotrexate is given. It is administered at a low dose for rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Methotrexate acts by two mechanisms at two different doses:

  • At low doses in Rheumatoid arthritis, it acts by inhibition of AICAR transformylase, thereby increasing the adenosine levels and exerting an anti-inflammatory effect.
  • At higher doses, as in Cancers, it acts by inhibiting Dihydrofolate reductase enzyme (DHFRase), thereby inhibiting the synthesis of pyrimidines and inhibiting the growth & multiplication of the tumour cells.

questions.text: A 10-year-old school child visits a primary care clinic for routine vaccinations as per the immunization program. The healthcare provider reviews the child's immunization records and plans to administer the appropriate vaccine to ensure the child's protection against preventable diseases. Which specific vaccine is recommended to be given during this visit?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. TT/Td

  • Based on the situation provided, a ten-year-old student is recommended to receive the TT/Td vaccine as per the National Immunization Schedule.
  • The Td vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria vaccines, with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen, and is recommended for older children and adults.
  • The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) advises the use of Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5 mL is injected into the upper arm muscle. This vaccine is given at the age of 10 and 16.
  • For pregnant women, Td-1 is given early in pregnancy and Td-2 is given 4 weeks after Td-1. A Td booster shot is recommended if a pregnancy occurs within 3 years of the last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were previously received.

Other options:

  • Option A – It refers to the BCG vaccine that is given at birth or as early as possible up to 1 year of age, as per the National Immunization Schedule. It provides protection against central nervous system tuberculosis and disseminated tuberculosis. A dose of 0.1 mL is injected intradermally in the left upper arm.
  • Option B – It is related to the Measles/MR vaccine, which is given at 9 completed months (first dose) and a second dose is administered at 16-24 months. This vaccine can be given until the age of 5 years. A dose of 0.5 mL is injected subcutaneously in the right upper arm.
  • Option D – It pertains to the DPT vaccine, which is a part of the pentavalent vaccine given at the 6th, 10th and 14th weeks of life. DPT booster doses are given at 16-24 months (first booster) and 5-6 years (second booster). It can be administered until the age of 7 with booster doses. A dose of 0.5 mL is injected into the anterolateral aspect of the mid-thigh.

questions.text: Name the parasite whose microfilaria have a sheath with no nuclei at the tail end.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Wuchereria bancrofti

  • A sheathed microfilaria with a pointed tail free of nuclei is suggestive of Wuchereria bancrofti.
  • Wuchereria bancrofti causes lymphatic filariasis and most cases are seen in India.

Clinical features:

  • Massive eosinophilia
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Pulmonary manifestations like dry nocturnal cough, asthmatic wheezing, and dyspnea.
  • It can also cause arthritis, glomerulonephritis, thrombophlebitis etc.
  • The classical features seen in lymphatic filariasis are usually absent.
  • Elephantiasis - It refers to the painful swelling of the legs and genital organs seen in late-stage disease.

questions.text: The most consistent and persistent feature of bladder carcinoma is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Painless hematuria

 

Bladder tumors classically produce painless hematuria. This is their dominant and sometimes only clinical manifestation. Frequency, urgency, and dysuria occasionally accompany the hematuria.

 

Bladder tumors produce a wide range of clinical features including:

  • Painless hematuria - Classical feature and may be the only clinical manifestation
  • Irritative urinary symptoms (frequency, urgency, dysuria) - diffuse tumors or tumors at the bladder neck
  • Pyelonephritis or hydronephrosis - when the ureteral orifice is involved
  • Obstructive symptoms, palpable suprapubic mass, or lower extremity edema - late presentation with a large tumor mass
  • Weight loss and/or localized bone pain - Metastatic disease

Option B: Painful hematuria is mainly seen in cases of UTIs, kidney injury, bladder trauma or urethral trauma.

questions.text:
2-year-old child was brought to the paediatric OPD with complaints of fever for a week duration with normal physical examination. A urine screening test was performed to rule out any inborn error of metabolism in the child and the results were,

 

Benedict’s test     -    positive

Blood Glucose     -   110 mg %

Bial’s test             -     positive

Urine glucose, fructose and galactose – Negative.

 

What is your most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A.  Essential pentosuria                     

  • Defect in glucuronic acid pathway results in essential pentosuria, a benign hereditary condition with excretion of xylulose in urine.
  • Due to absence of the enzyme xylulose reductase which reduces xylulose to xylitol.
  • Xylulose being a reducing sugar gives false positive results during Benedict’s test.

 

Bial test is used to differentiate pentoses from hexoses. Pentoses give blue-green colored complex.

 

Incorrect answers:

 

False: Option (b) Essential fructosuria: Due to deficiency of fructokinase with excretion of fructose in urine, gives positive Benedict’s and Seliwanoff’s tests.

 

False: Option (c) Hereditary fructose intolerance: When sucrose (containing fructose) is introduced in the diet of infants, due to defect in aldolase-B → fructose-1- phosphate cannot be metabolized and fructose is excreted in urine gives positive Benedict’s test.

 

False: Option (d) Galactosemia: Due to deficiency of enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase and clinical manifestation include congenital cataract, presence of galactose in urine and elevated blood galactose levels.

Ans. D. Should have a 100-bed facility in metro cities 

 

Urban Community Health Centre (U-CHC) has 100 bedded in Metro cities:

  2. One U-CHC to be established for every 2.5 lakh population with an inpatient facility that is 30-50 bedded.

questions.text: What should be done in the case of a 15-year-old girl who is non-compliant with wearing spectacles for her myopic astigmatism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Spherical equivalent spectacles

 

The appropriate management for myopic astigmatism in a 15-year-old girl (<18 years) would be spherical equivalent spectacles.

 

The three components of prescription in astigmatism are:

  • Power of the spherical component, indicated by a positive (+) or negative (-) dioptre sphere (DS).
  • Power of the cylindrical component, indicated by a positive (+) or negative (-) dioptre cylinder (DC).
  • Axis or orientation of the cylinder.

Calculation of Spherical equivalent:

  • The cylinder power and axis are correcting the astigmatic part of the refractive error. If an astigmatic eye were to be corrected with a spherical lens alone, the result would be a blur circle on the retina, called the circle of least confusion.
  • The spherical lens power places the circle of least confusion on the retina and is called the spherical equivalent. It is defined as the spherical power whose focal point coincides with the circle of least confusion, where one would see minimal blurring in their vision.
  • To calculate the spherical equivalent, add half the cylinder power to the sphere power:
    Spherical equivalent = Spherical power + 1/2 (Cylindrical power)
    • For example, for spherical power +2 and cylindrical power +3 +2.00 +(+3.00 /2) = +3.50.
       
  • Spherical equivalent spectacles are given if one has to give less cylinder power than was measured.

Other options:

  • Options A and C - LASIK and Femto LASIK should be done in patients above 18 years of age.
  • Option D - Implantable Collamer lens is indicated for patients 21-45 years of age. The image demonstrates the steps of LASIK.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with severe backache for 10 days and urinary incontinence with a history of intervertebral lumbar disc prolapse. There is no H/o fever or weight loss. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cauda equina syndrome

 

Cauda Equina Syndrome:

  • Cauda equina syndrome results from compression (squeezing) of the cauda equine, i.e., the sac of nerves and nerve roots at the base and just below the spinal cord in the lumbosacral spinal canal.
  • It is a rare but serious disorder, and a medical emergency.
  • The nerves of the cauda equina provide motor and sensory function to the legs and the bladder.
  • Compression of these nerves can interrupt their function, and the effects can be severe.

Causes:

  • Lumbar disc herniation
  • Trauma
  • Spinal tumor
  • Spinal stenosis
  • Infection
  • Vertebral fractures from osteoporosis

Symptoms:

  • Severe low back pain
  • Bladder dysfunction such as urinary retention or incontinence
  • Bowel incontinence
  • Muscle weakness or sensory loss in both legs
  • Loss of motor function in legs
  • Loss or reduction of reflexes
  • Saddle anesthesia (inability to feel anything in the body areas that would sit on a saddle)

Investigations:

  • Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging:
    • The best method of imaging the spinal cord, nerve roots, intervertebral discs, and ligaments.
    • Since, these scans can detect damage or disease of soft tissue, MRIs are valuable in diagnosing the cause of cauda equina syndrome.
       
  • Myelogram:
    • Procedure that involves injecting a liquid dye into the spinal column.
    • These X-ray and CT images [usually performed with a computerized tomography (CT) scan] can show pressure on the cauda equina from herniated discs and other conditions.

Treatment:

  • Cauda equina syndrome is a potential surgical emergency, and may require timely decompression surgery to reduce/remove the pressure on the nerve(s).
  • Undergoing early surgery seems to offer the best chance for improvement of sensory and muscle function as well as bowel and bladder function.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food at a party. Which of the following organism is most likely to cause these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Staphylococcus aureus

  • The most likely causative organism in the given scenario is Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.
  • The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches.
  • Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhoea.

questions.text: A woman arrives at the outpatient department with a history of 6 weeks of not having her menstrual periods (amenorrhea). She complains of vaginal bleeding and experiences mild abdominal pain. A urine pregnancy test confirms she is pregnant, and her human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) level is measured at 2800 IU/L. Further investigation reveals the presence of a 3 x 2 cm mass on the left adnexa. Fortunately, her vital signs are stable. How would you approach the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Single-dose methotrexate injection

 

Given clinical scenario with hemodynamically stable patient points to a diagnosis of Unruptured ectopic pregnancy.

 

MANAGEMENT OF UNRUPTURED ECTOPIC

 

 

SURGICAL MANAGEMENT IN UNRUPTURED ECTOPIC

 

Indicated in:

i. An ectopic pregnancy and significant pain.

ii. An ectopic pregnancy with an adnexal mass of 35 mm or larger.

iii. An ectopic pregnancy with a fetal heartbeat visible on an ultrasound scan.

iv. An ectopic pregnancy and a serum bhCG level of 5,000 IU/L or more.

 

Laparoscopy is preferred for

  1. SALPINGECTOMY Preferred if:
    • Extensive tubal involvement/damage.
    • Recurrent ectopic pregnancy in the same tube.
    • Completed family.
    • Ectopic at the site of a previous tubal sterilization.
       
  2. SALPINGOSTOMY (Linear incision on the antimesenteric border with removal of products of conception) Done if a woman wants to conceive in the future.

questions.text: A patient presents with a clean-cut injury that is not lacerated. The patient reports having received a tetanus vaccination about 10 years ago. What is the appropriate course of action for the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Single dose tetanus toxoid

 

A single dose of tetanus toxoid is given as the wound is clean and the last dose was received more than 10 years ago.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with complaints of memory difficulties and difficulty forming new memories. Upon examination, you notice bilateral damage to a certain structure in the brain that is involved in memory consolidation and recall. The treating doctor noted the following structure, which was damaged and led to the above signs and symptoms. Identify the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fornix

  • The image given shows a mid-sagittal section of the brain.
  • The structure marked is the Fornix.
  • The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of white matter located in the mesial hemispheres of the brain, just below the corpus callosum.
  • The fornix is an important part of the limbic system, and it is the hippocampus's largest single pathway, connecting it to various subcortical structures.

questions.text: Glycogen phosphorylase can be regulated by all the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Glycogenin

 

Glycogenin is a protein that acts as a starting material on which initial glucose is added in the synthesis of Glycogen.

 

Regulation of Glycogen metabolism at Glycogen Phosphorylase:

  • cAMP activates Glycogen Phosphorylase by cAMP dependent Protein Kinase
  • cAMP-independent Calcium/Calmodulin - directly activates Phosphorylase.
  • Kinase also activates Glycogen Phosphorylase.

questions.text: What process is accountable for the absorption of glucose into the intestine among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Secondary active transport

 

Glucose is absorbed into the intestine by secondary active transport because this process allows for the efficient uptake of glucose against its concentration gradient.

 

Secondary active transport involves the coupled movement of two substances across a membrane, where the movement of one substance is dependent on the electrochemical gradient created by the movement of another substance.

 

In the case of glucose absorption in the intestine, the secondary active transport mechanism relies on the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump.

 

The process of glucose absorption in the intestine occurs in the brush border membrane of the intestinal epithelial cells, specifically in the small intestine.

 

Here's a step-by-step explanation of how secondary active transport facilitates glucose absorption:

  1. Sodium-Potassium Pump: The sodium-potassium pump actively transports sodium ions (Na+) out of the epithelial cells and into the intercellular space, using ATP energy. This creates a concentration gradient, where, the sodium concentration is higher outside the cell.
  2. Sodium-Glucose Co-transporter: The sodium gradient generated by the sodium-potassium pump is utilized by a specific protein called the sodium-glucose co-transporter (SGLT). This co-transporter binds both sodium ions and glucose molecules on the outer surface of the cell.
  3. Co-transport of Sodium and Glucose: As sodium ions bind to the SGLT protein, their movement into the cell down the concentration gradient provides the necessary energy for the simultaneous movement of glucose against its concentration gradient. Glucose is "dragged" along with the sodium ions as they enter the cell.
  4. Glucose Transporter: Once inside the epithelial cell, glucose is transported across the basolateral membrane (the inner surface of the cell) and into the bloodstream by facilitated diffusion through a specific glucose transporter called GLUT2.

Overall, the energy stored in the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump is used to actively transport both sodium and glucose into the intestinal epithelial cells. This secondary active transport mechanism allows for the absorption of glucose from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream efficiently, even when the concentration of glucose is higher inside the cell than in the lumen.

questions.text: The air pollution index chart of 4 consecutive days in Delhi station is given below. The air quality index of November 23 is classified as?

According to the data presented in the question, the air quality index for the 23rd of November is 407, which is classified as severe.

 

Air Quality Index (AQI) -

 

A tool used for effective communication of air quality status on a scale that is easily comprehensible.

 

Complex air quality data of various pollutants are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature and colour that determines the air pollution of that particular location.

 

Eight pollutants are taken into consideration to calculate the AQI:

  • PM10 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 10 microns or less)
  • PM2.5 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 microns or less)
  • NO2 (Nitrogen dioxide)
  • SO2 (Sulfur dioxide)
  • CO (Carbon monoxide)
  • 03 (Ozone/Trioxygen)
  • NH3 (Ammonia)
  • Pb (Lead)

Myringotomy with grommet insertion

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents to OPD with pain in the left ear which was of sudden onset and associated with hardness of hearing. On examination, a red, bulged tympanic membrane was found. What is the next step in the management of this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Conservative management

 

From the history, it is evident that the child is suffering from acute suppurative otitis media (sudden onset pain in a child indicates acute otitis media unless until proved otherwise). A red, bulging tympanic membrane is due to accumulation of pus in the middle ear. This causes pressure over tympanic membrane and causes severe pain to the child.

 

Acute Suppurative Otitis Media:

 

It is divided into 4 stages

  1. Tubal occlusion
  2. Hyperemia / pre-suppuration
  3. Suppuration
  4. Resolution / complication.

Most common organisms are Streptococcus pneumonia & Haemophilus influenza.

 

 

Management:

  • Conservative management is given initially in case of ASOM.
  • Myringotomy with grommet insertion is done for serous otitis media.
  • If Eustachian tube blockage continues for prolonged periods and no organism invades, then the fluid collected inside middle ear will be sterile (non-infective).
  • This condition is called ‘Otitis media with effusion / Serous otitis media / Glue ear.’
  • Here, there is no complaint of pain as there is no infection or inflammation.
  • Common causes include hypertrophied adenoids + tonsils or cleft palate or inadequate ASOM treatment (Biofilm formation by the bacteria can resist antibiotics and hence, they persist inside even after antibiotic course and causes excess irritation of mucosa thereby causing excess fluid secretion. Here, the fluid is sterile on testing because bacteria are not free-floating).
  • To drain the fluid, myringotomy (a small opening in tympanic membrane) is done and all the fluid will now drain outside. Most common site for myringotomy is antero-inferior quadrant. Radial type of incision given here (curvilinear incision is given in ASOM).
  • Grommet (ventilation tube) inserted through myringotomy for permanent drainage of freshly forming fluid. If hypertrophied adenoids are the cause found, then adenoidectomy should be done at the same time.

 

OME in an elderly person should be suspected for nasopharyngeal carcinoma (Fossa of Rosenmuller – most common site). Mostly it will be unilateral. Fluctuating conductive hearing loss is seen in OME (Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss is seen in Meniere’s disease).

  • Tympanoplasty is done for chronic otitis media of mucosal type.

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. What is the nature of the causative virus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Enveloped ss RNA

  • The given clinical vignette is suggestive of measles. Measles virus is a Paramyxovirus which is an enveloped, single-stranded RNA (ss RNA) virus.
  • The onset of rashes after the development of Koplik spots that are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the inner aspect of the cheek at the level of premolars, with associated features of coryza, and conjunctivitis is suggestive of measles.

Measles:

  •  
  • The virus has an incubation period of 8-12 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots.
  • This is followed by the appearance of maculopapular rash after 4th day of fever, which begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities.
  • Patients can transmit infection 3 days before and 4-6 days after the onset of rash.
  • Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic of measles.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to trauma centre after skid injury, and he is unable to pass urine with blood at meatus. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. SPC

 

Based on the symptoms described, it is possible that the boy has sustained a urethral injury or obstruction. The next step in management would be to relieve the obstruction and drain the bladder via Suprapubic catheterisation (SPC).

 

Foley's catheterization (option B) is contraindicated in patients with urethral injury. Option C (MCU) can be ruled out as it needs Foley’s catheterisation to inject the contrast in the bladder.

questions.text: Following a coronary bypass graft procedure utilizing the great saphenous vein, a 56-year-old patient reports experiencing paraesthesia and reduced sensation along the medial aspect of their leg and foot. Which nerve is the most likely candidate for involvement in this scenario, potentially explaining the patient's neurological symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Saphenous nerve

  • The patient's symptoms of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot indicate possible damage to the saphenous nerve, which can occur during a venous cutdown procedure to access the great saphenous vein for coronary bypass graft.

Saphenous nerve:

  • The saphenous nerve is a major cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body.
  • After arising from the posterior division of the femoral nerve, it enters and exits the adductor canal before piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius muscles.
  • From there, it runs along the medial border of the tibia alongside the great saphenous vein and supplies sensation to the skin over the patella, knee, leg, and foot, up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.
  • During a venous cutdown procedure, injury to the saphenous nerve is common due to its proximity to the great saphenous vein.
  • The resulting sensory loss typically affects the medial aspect of the knee, leg, and foot.

questions.text:
You are working in a primary health center (PHC) situated in a high seismic zone. Which of the following will you do as part of preparedness for an emergency?

  1. Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources is available
  2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers
  3. Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response
  4. Follow instructions given over the phone or radio by higher officials
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 2, 3

 

Steps 1, 2, and 3 are done as part of preparedness for an emergency by someone working in a PHC situated in a high seismic zone.

 

Roles and responsibilities of medical officer of PHC when posted in Seismic areas:

  1. Ensure funds and resources are available and can be mobilized at the time of disaster for quick evacuation.
  2. Preparedness to handle emergency.
  3. Disaster simulation practices and then check the response.

Emergency preparedness refers to long-term development activities that strengthen the capacity of a country to effectively manage all kinds of emergencies.

 

It involves the following steps:

  1. Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources is available.
  2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers.
  3. Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response.
  4. Evaluate the risk of disaster.
  5. Information sessions coordination with news media.
  6. Adopt standards and regulations.

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cytomegalovirus

  • The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).
  • The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever (most common), leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia.

Other options: JC virus, BK virus, and Epstein-Barr virus also have the propensity to cause infections during this period, but in lesser frequencies than CMV.

questions.text:
Assertion: Decompression surgery is needed with progressive neurological difficulty in Pott’s spine.

 

Reason: Even after completion of ATT there can be neurological abnormalities.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion

 

Pott’s Spine

  • Like tuberculosis of the bones and joints elsewhere in the body, TB of the spine is always secondary.
  • The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes.
  • Types of vertebral tuberculosis:
  1. Paradiscal: This is the commonest type. In this, the contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae along with the intervening disc are affected.
  2. Central: In this type, the body of a single vertebra is affected. This leads to early collapse of the weakened vertebra. The nearby disc may be normal. The collapse may be a ‘wedging’ or ‘concertina’ collapse; wedging being more common.
  3. Anterior: In this type, infection is localized to the anterior part of the vertebral body. The infection spreads up and down under the anterior longitudinal ligament.
  4. Posterior: In this type, the posterior complex of the vertebra, i.e., the pedicle, lamina, spinous process and transverse process are affected.
  • Clinical features: Pain, stiffness, cold abscess formation, paraplegia, deformity, fever, and weight loss.
  • Imaging:
  • Plain radiograph:
    • Reduction of disc space
    • Vertebral body destruction
    • Paravertebral abscess
    • Widening of mediastinum
       
  • CT scan: It may detect a small paravertebral abscess, not otherwise seen on plain X-ray, indicating precisely the extent of destruction of the vertebral body and posterior elements; and may show a sequestrum or a bony ridge pressing on the cord.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord. It also shows condition of the underlying neural tissues, and thus helps in predicting the prognosis in a particular case.
  • Biopsy: CT-guided needle biopsy, or an open biopsy may be required in a case with doubtful diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
  • Middle path regimen is used in India.
    • Patient is treated with antitubercular therapy (ATT), spinal brace and rest.
    • Patient is followed on with complete neurological examination and if progress is good, then continued on non-operative management, but if indications of surgery exists, then they must be operated.
       
  • Stage-wise Treatment:
    • Stage 1: ATT + rest + monthly neural examination
    • Stage 2: ATT + rest + weekly neural examination
    • Stage 3: ATT + rest + daily neural examination
    • Stage 4: ATT + Decompression and bone grafting
       
  • ATT:
    • Rifampicin is always a part of all regimens.
    • Minimum duration is 9-12 months in spinal TB and may be given up to 18-24 months depending upon clinical, radiological (MRI) and hematological (ESR) healing (in non-spinal TB the duration of ATT is 6 months-1 year).
       
  • Indications of surgery in any disease of spine (including all pathologies of spine – trauma, tumor, TB, disc prolapse)
    • Bowel bladder involvement
    • Deterioration in neural or clinical status on treatment
    • No improvement in neural or clinical status after conservative trial of 3-4 weeks
       
  • Surgical options for most of the cases are anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting and both have similar success rates.
  • Hong Kong operation is also carried out for Pott’s spine, i.e.,
    • Structures removed in anterolateral decompression are part of rib, one side transverse process, one pedicle and small part of vertebral body (intercostal nerves are exposed).

 

Structures removed in anterolateral decompression

  • Posterior structures like lamina are never removed in tuberculosis because disease destroys anteriorly and if surgeon  destroys posteriorly, then there will be instability.
  • This surgery is carried out in right lateral position (right side down and left side up) approaching the spine from left side as the vessel handled is aorta on left side which is thick muscular vessel with more resilience to handling  pressure as compared to vena cava on right side which is friable to handle.

Prognostic Factors:

 

 

  • Immunomodulation:
    • In case response to ATT is not on the expected ground and it is suspected that patient’s immune system is not controlling the disease, then immunomodulation is done to enhance the immune response.
    • In immunomodulation the bacilli attacked are – dormant/resistant/persistent/slow grower/atypical M. tuberculosis
    • Drugs given are:
      1. Levamisole
      2. BCG
      3. DPT
    • Treatment: ATT + Rest + Surgery when indicated
  • Indications of surgery in any disease of spine:
    • Bowel bladder involvement
    • Worsening
    • No improvement

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with anorexia, nausea, vomiting and epigastric pain radiating towards the back. The following appearance was noted on his abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute Pancreatitis

 

Given scenario is suggestive of Acute haemorrhagic Pancreatitis demonstrating Cullen’s sign.

 

Symptoms of Acute Pancreatitis:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Pain typically radiates to back and is relieved in the sitting forward position.
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs of Acute Pancreatitis:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea.
  • Grey Turner’s sign: Bluish discoloration of the flanks because of bleeding in fascial plane.

  • Cullen’s sign: Bleeding into the fascial planes can produce bluish discoloration of umbilicus.

NOTE: Both of them are not pathognomonic to acute pancreatitis.

 

Diagnosis: Any 2 out of 3 criteria

  1. Acute epigastric pain often radiating to the back.
  2. Serum amylase or lipase (more specific) to 3 x Upper limit of normal.
  3. Characteristic imaging findings.

questions.text: A 35-year-old chronic hypertensive woman visits the outpatient department for pre conceptional counselling. Which of the following anti-hypertensive should not be given to her?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors
 

ACE-Inhibitors and ARBs are contraindicated in pregnancy as they lead to fetal renal hypoperfusion or can even lead to renal agenesis-leading to oliguria/anuria. The decrease in urine output can cause oligohydramnios, which can in turn lead to pulmonary hypoplasia and limb reduction defects.
 

The other antihypertensives that are contraindicated in pregnancy are Diuretics, Non-selective Beta blockers like Propranolol and sodium nitroprusside.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset weakness and sensory changes in his lower extremities and one side of his body. Based on the clinical history and examination findings, John Doe is diagnosed with Brown-Sequard syndrome. What is the true statement about Brown-Sequard syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
 

Hemi-sectioning of the spinal cord involves the ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown- Sequard syndrome.

 

 

Effects of hemi-sectioning (Brown-Sequard Syndrome) of spinal cord:

 

A. Below the level of lesion

 

 

B. At the level of lesion

 

 

Functions of tracts involved:

  • Fasciculus gracilis or fasciculus cuneatus → Ipsilateral discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception.
  • Spinothalamic tract → Contralateral pain and temperature sensation.
  • Corticospinal tract → Primary motor activity same side of the body.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male arrived at the clinic with a complaint of gradual loss of clear vision, sensitivity to light, and discomfort in his eye. During the examination, the doctor observed redness in the conjunctiva, a partially dilated pupil, and a shallow anterior chamber in his right eye. Despite receiving medical and surgical treatment for his condition, there was no noticeable improvement. The subsequent procedure introduced a specialized device designed to facilitate drainage. Identify the device?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ex-Press™ implant

 

The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of glaucoma not responsive to medical treatment and trabeculectomy and the device used is Ex-Press™ glaucoma implant (mini shunt).

 

It is a minimally invasive glaucoma surgery (MIGS) to increase aqueous drainage.

 

A tiny stainless-steel implant called Ex-PRESS is used to treat glaucoma.

 

It is implanted during a modified trabeculectomy underneath a scleral flap.

 

Hypotony-related complications are less common than with conventional trabeculectomy.

 

By creating a communication between the anterior chamber and the sub-space/sub-conjunctival Tennon's space, glaucoma drainage devices enable aqueous outflow. While formerly only used in high-risk patients or after a failed trabulectomy, these devices are gaining popularity.

 

The commonly used devices are as follows:

  • ﻿﻿Shunts using episcleral explants
  • ﻿﻿Ahmed glaucoma valve - Silicone
  • ﻿﻿Molteno implant- Polypropelene plate and silicone plate
  • ﻿﻿Baerveldt implant - Silicone
  • ﻿﻿Mini-shunts
  • ﻿﻿Ex-Press™ implant Mini-Shunt: Stainless steel
  • ﻿﻿iStent®- Titanium

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient diagnosed with diabetes visited with complaints of a squint. During examination, it was noted that the secondary deviation exceeded the primary deviation. The forced duction test yielded negative results. Based on these findings, what type of squint is most probable in this patient?

Ans. C. Paralytic squint

 

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of paralytic squint. It is characterized by the presence of secondary deviation more than the primary deviation, and a negative forced duction test.

 

The squint may be either comitant or incomitant:

  • Comitant squint: The angle of squint measured is same in all gazes.
  • Incomitant squint: The angle of squint measured is different in different gazes.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct formula for calculation of the maintenance dose rate of a drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Clearance x Plasma concentration

 

In a steady state plasma concentration, the amount of drug eliminated from the body is equal to the amount of drug that is administered, i.e., the maintenance dose.

 

To calculate the maintenance dose, we have to take into consideration the clearance as well as the desired plasma concentration.

 

Therefore,

 

Maintenance dosing rate (for IV drugs) = Clearance x Plasma Concentration.

questions.text: Thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

 

WISKOTT-ALDRICH SYNDROME (WAS)

  • It is a complex, recessive, X-linked disease

Mutations:

  • WASP gene (affect not only T lymphocytes but also the other lymphocyte subsets, dendritic cells, and platelets).

Pathophysiology:

  • WASP regulates the actin cytoskeleton and thus plays an important role in many lymphocyte functions, including cell adhesion and migration and the formation of synapses between antigen-presenting cell and target cells.

Clinical manifestations:

  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Eczema
  • Bleeding caused by thrombocytopenia
  • Null mutations predispose affected individuals to invasive and bronchopulmonary infections, viral infections, severe eczema, and autoimmune manifestations.

Diagnosis:

  • Reduced-sized platelets on a blood smear.
  • Intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of WAS protein (WASP) expression in blood cells.

Treatment:

  • According to the severity of disease expression.
  • Prophylactic antibiotics, immunoglobulin G (IgG) supplementation, and careful topical treatment of eczema.
  • Although splenectomy improves platelet count in a majority of cases, this intervention is associated with a significant risk of infection (both before and after HSCT).
  • Allogeneic HSCT is curative, with fairly good results overall.

Other options:

  • Option B - Chediak higashi occurs due to LyST (Lysosomal transfer protein) defect characterized by recurrent infections, oculo-cutaneous albinism.
  • Option C - TAR is associated with thrombocytopenia at birth.
  • Option D - Hermansky-Pudlak occurs due to deficiency of dense granules in platelets characterized by oculocutaneous albinism, ILD, Granulomatous colitis.

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Immunodeficiencies/Chapter 351,374

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the clinic with a complaint of the feeling of insects crawling under the skin. Which of the following drug abuse can cause the symptoms of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cocaine

 

Cocaine abuse is characterised by the sensation of insects crawling under the skin, also known as cocaine bugs or formication.

 

Other features of acute cocaine intoxication are delusions of persecution, paranoia, and suspiciousness. It is essential to differentiate acute cocaine intoxication from acute schizophrenia which it closely resembles.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with the history of angina has presented to the OPD. He is prescribed a drug which acts by inhibiting the late sodium current in the heart. Which of the following drugs is being prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ranolazine

  • Ranolazine is an anti-anginal drug, that is a Fatty acid oxidation inhibitor (Another one being Trimetazidine), that acts by decreasing the oxygen demand of the heart by making it utilize glucose as the source of ATP.
  • Ranolazine also acts on the late Na+ channel in the heart, which helps in reducing the intracellular calcium concentration, thereby reducing the diastolic tension and the cardiac contractility.

Other options:

  • Ivabradine is a Funny current blocker, that blocks the hyperpolarization activated sodium channels.
  • Fasudil is a Rho-kinase inhibitor that causes vasodilatation.

  • Check ocular fundus before HCQ initiation
  • Leflunomide, sulfasalazine other group of drugs.
  • Sulfasalazine is safe in pregnancy!!

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatoid arthritis/ Chap 358

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient with a history of heart attacks (MIs) and strokes (CVAs). His blood work shows an elevated homocysteine level, which is reduced after the patient takes pharmacological doses of pyridoxamine. An enzyme that would benefit from such treatment in lowering homocysteine levels is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Cystathionine β-synthase

  • Cystathionine β-synthase requires pyridoxal phosphate for its functions.
  • Hence, by increasing the concentration of B6, in about 50% of the cases of defective synthase enzymes, the symptoms can be overcome.

Incorrect answers:

  • FALSE: Option (a) Methionine synthase: Defect in methionine synthase will cause elevated homocysteine levels and it requires B12 not B6.
  • FALSE: Option (b) N5, N10 methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase: A defect in this enzyme leads to elevated homocysteine but that enzyme has a requirement for NADH not vitamin B6.
  • FALSE: Option (d) Cystathionase: A defect in cystathionase (another B6 requiring enzyme) will block the degradation of cystathionine causing accumulation of the same but will not lead to significantly elevated homocysteine.

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 221.

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presented with gradually developing motor weakness, stiffness in the neck, and challenges with swallowing and performing daily tasks. The initial assessment points to a potential case of multiple sclerosis. Which types of cells are impacted by multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oligodendrocytes

 

Oligodendrocytes are affected in multiple sclerosis.

 

In multiple sclerosis (MS), myelin-forming oligodendrocytes (OLGs) are the targets of inflammatory and immune attacks. OLG death by apoptosis or necrosis causes the cell loss seen in MS plaques, and leads to loss of conduction or delayed conduction in the demyelinated axons.

 

Other options:

 

Option A: Microglia are the primary immune cells of the central nervous system, similar to peripheral macrophages.

 

Option C: Astrocytes, also known collectively as astroglia, are characteristic star-shaped glial cells in the brain and spinal cord. They perform many functions, including biochemical control of endothelial cells that form the blood–brain barrier.

 

Option D: Ependymal cells are ciliated-epithelial glial cells that develop from radial glia along the surface of the ventricles of the brain and the spinal canal. They play a critical role in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) homeostasis, brain metabolism, and the clearance of waste from the brain.

questions.text: Gastric lavage can be performed in case of poisoning by?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Carbolic acid

 

Gastric lavage can be performed in case of carbolic poisoning. It is a corrosive acid, but it hardens the Gl mucosa thus anesthetizing its nerve endings and allows for gastric lavage.

 

Contraindications to gastric lavage:

  1. Corrosive poisons such as concentrated inorganic acids (e.g. sulfuric acid, nitric acid etc.) corrode and soften the stomach wall, making it prone for perforation (exception carbolic acid which hardens the stomach wall and gastric lavage is done safely).
  2. Risk of aspiration: Convulsive poisons, Comatose patients, Volatile poisons (hydrocarbons like kerosene)
  3. Upper gastrointestinal tract diseases: Example oesophageal varices
  4. Hypothermia
  5. Haemorrhagic diathesis

choices.text: Vitamin B12 deficiency

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a history of muscle weakness, forgetfulness, loss of appetite and tremors in hand and involuntary movements of eyes. He is a known alcoholic for the past 12 years. On examination, he has an unsteady gait, fine tremors and mental confusion. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Wernicke-Korsakoff Psychosis

 

Clinical Features: Encephalopathy + ophthalmoplegia + nystagmus + cerebellar ataxia + psychosis. Seen in severe nutritional deficiency.

  • Polyneuritis is common in chronic alcoholics.
  • Alcohol utilization requires large doses of thiamine; hence it inhibits intestinal absorption of thiamine leading to thiamine deficiency.
  • Deficiency causes impairment of conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA → increased plasma concentration of pyruvate and lactate→ lactic acidosis.

Incorrect answers:

 

FALSE: Option (b) Dry beriberi: Here CNS manifestations such as peripheral neuritis with sensory disturbance resulting in complete paralysis occurs.

 

FALSE: Option (c) Wet beriberi: Here CVS manifestations are prominent which are edema of legs, face, trunk and serous cavities and palpitation, breathlessness and distended neck veins. Finally, death occurs due to heart failure.

 

FALSE: Option (d) Vitamin B12: includes Megaloblastic anemia, Homocystinuria, Demyelination, Subacute combined degeneration and Achlorhydria.

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 478.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient has been diagnosed with Carcinoma bladder for which he was receiving chemotherapy. Two days later he developed intractable vomiting. Which of the following anti-emetics that should be prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aprepitant

 

Aprepitant is a Neurokinin receptor antagonist which is used in management of delayed onset vomiting after chemotherapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Tegaserod acts as a partial agonist at serotonin 5-HT4 receptors in the gastrointestinal tract. By stimulating these receptors, tegaserod enhances the release of acetylcholine and other neurotransmitters, leading to increased gut motility and accelerated transit of stool through the intestines. This helps relieve constipation and improve symptoms associated with IBS-C.

 

Option C) Granisetron is a 5HT3 receptor blocker. These 5HT3 receptor blockers are the most effective antiemetics for chemotherapy induced nausea and vomiting and is indicated in early onset chemotherapy induced nausea and vomiting

 

Option D) Doxylamine is an antihistamine medication which is indicated along with Pyridoxine in management of Morning sickness in early pregnancy.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with diabetes visits you, reporting a visual acuity of 6/9 in one eye. Subsequent investigations unveil the presence of pre-retinal hemorrhage accompanied by neovascularization at the optic disc. What would be the subsequent course of action for management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pan-retinal photocoagulation

 

The clinical vignette is suggestive of proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics and the next step in management is pan-retinal photocoagulation.

 

 

 

Diabetic retinopathy is used to describe retinal changes seen in diabetic patients. It is classified into the following types:
 

  • Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR)
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR)
  • Diabetic maculopathy
  • Advanced diabetic eye disease

 

Fundoscopy in NPDR reveals hard exudates, cotton-wool spots, and microaneurysms. Hard exudates are small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with created margins.

 

Other Options:

Option A) Focal Laser Photocoagulation and Option C) Grid Laser Photocoagulation: These are often used to treat diabetic macular edema.

 

Option D) Scleral Buckling: it is a procedure which involves placing a silicone band (buckle) on the outer layer of the eye. It is used to treat retinal detachment.

questions.text: According to NCEP-ATP III guidelines, which of the following is not considered a criterion for metabolic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. High LDL

 

As per NCEP- ATP III, high LDL is not included in the definition criteria of metabolic syndrome.

 

Metabolic syndrome is present if three or more of the following five criteria are met, which is given by NCEP-ATP III (National Cholesterol Education Program and Adult Treatment Panel III). It includes:

  • Central obesity: waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: triglyceride level ≥ 150 mg/dL
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively.
  • Hypertension: blood pressure ≥130 mmHg systolic or ≥ 85 mmHg diastolic.
  • Fasting plasma glucose level: ≥100 mg/dL or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: Pick out the false statement about mitochondrial DNA:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Transmit in classical mendelian fashion                   

                                                     

MAJOR FEATURES OF HUMAN MITOCHONDRIAL DNA -

  • Is circular, double stranded
  • Contains 16,569 bp
  • Encodes 13 protein subunits of respiratory chain (of total of about 67)
    • Seven subunits of NADPH dehydrogenase (complex I) cytochrome b of complex III
    • Three subunits of cytochrome oxidase (complex IV)
    • Two subunits of ATP synthase
       
  • Encodes large (165) and small (125) mitochondrial ribosomal rnas
  • Encodes 2 mitochondrial trna molecules
  • Genetic code differs slightly from the standard code
  • UGA (stop codon) is read as Trp AGA and AGG (codon for ARG) are read as stop codon
  • Contains very few untranslated sequences
  • High mutation rate (5-10 times that of nuclear DNA)
  • Comparisons of mtdna sequences provide evidence about evolutionary origins of primates and other species

The Mitochondrial genome of the mother is transferred to all of its offspring.

 

Diseases due to mutation in mitochondrial genome:

  1. MELAS – Mitochondrial Encephalopathy Lactic Acidosis and Stroke like episode
  2. Leigh Syndrome        
  3. Leber Hereditary Optic Neuropathy
  4. NARP Syndrome - Neuropathy, Ataxia, Retinitis Pigmentosa
  5. MERRF - Myoclonic Epilepsy and Ragged Red Fibres in muscles
  6. CPEO - Chronic Progressive External Ophthalmoplegia
  7. Kearns Sayre Syndrome
  8. Pearson Syndrome- Lactic Acidosis, Pancreatic Insufficiency, Pancytopenia

Incorrect answers:

 

False: Option (a), Option (b) and Option (c): all are TRUE.

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 378.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Luteinizing hormone
﻿﻿﻿Follicular stimulating hormone

questions.text: Which hormone acts on post ovulatory endometrium is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Progesterone

 

Post ovulation, there is rise in the progesterone levels. Progesterone helps in bringing the secretory changes in the endometrium thereby preparing the endometrium for implantation.

 

The normal menstrual cycle consists of the following phases:

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Menstruation (0 - 4 days)
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Follicular phase (10 -14 days)
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Ovulation (14th day)
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Luteal phase (14 - 28)

 

Menstrual Phase: It begins with menstruation. At the beginning of this phase, Estrogen and progesterone levels are low. During this phase, with the drop in the hormonal levels, the endometrial lining is shed. The bleeding lasts for about 3-7 days.

 

Follicular Phase: This phase begins when the bleeding stops. FSH and LH levels start to rise stimulating the development of the follicles. As the follicles grow, Estrogen levels increase which helps thicken the uterine lining. Therefore, this phase is also known as Proliferation Phase. It is also called as pre-ovulatory phase as it precedes the ovulation.

 

Ovulatory Phase or Ovulation: It is the process where a mature follicle releases an egg from the ovary. This usually occurs around the day 14th of the cycle. The surge in the LH levels triggers ovulation.

 

Luteal Phase or Post-ovulatory Phase: After ovulation, the ruptured follicle forms the corpus luteum, which produces progesterone. It helps in maintaining the uterine lining and prepares for possible pregnancy. The uterine lining thickens under the influence of progesterone. If the corpus luteum degenerates, there is no source of progesterone to support the uterine lining. It, therefore, sheds off in the next phase.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in a preterm neonate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypothermia

 

Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) is a common respiratory disorder in preterm neonates due to inadequate surfactant production. Hypothermia is a characteristic feature of RDS. Surfactant deficiency leads to increased surface tension within the alveoli, causing collapse and reduced lung compliance. As a result, affected neonates have difficulty maintaining their body temperature, which can lead to hypothermia.

 

The other options (A, B, and D) are not directly associated with RDS. While hyperglycemia, hypernatremia, and hypocalcemia can occur in preterm neonates for various reasons, they are not specific features of RDS

choices.text: Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)
Coarctation of the Aorta

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with exertional dyspnea, palpitations, and a systolic ejection murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border. An echocardiogram reveals hypertrophy of the interventricular septum. Which condition is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

 

The presentation of exertional dyspnoea, palpitations, a systolic ejection murmur, and hypertrophy of the interventricular septum is indicative of Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM).

 

HCM is characterized by asymmetric septal hypertrophy, leading to left ventricular outflow obstruction. The murmur is a result of the turbulent blood flow through the narrowed outflow tract.

 

It occurs due to an autosomal dominant defect in the myosin chain of cardiac muscle fibers.

 

On echocardiography, there is a banana-shaped ventricular cavity and systolic displacement of anterior mitral valve leaflet.

 

 

Options A, B, and D can be ruled out because they do not typically present with septal hypertrophy or the given clinical features.

choices.text: The efficacy of the drug b and c are equal
Drug A is the most potent drug
Drug C is less potent and equally efficacious to drug B
Drug D is more potent than drugs A, B, & C, but less efficacious than drugs A & B, and equally efficacious as drug C

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the given dose-response curve.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Drug D is more potent than drugs A, B, & C, but less efficacious than drugs A & B, and equally efficacious as drug C

 

The above given image is that of a Log Dose-Response curve, where on the X axis we plot the Log concentration of the drug and on the Y axis we plot the Response. From this type of curve, we can know about the following 3 parameters about a drug:

  •  Potency – Potency means the power of a drug. The drug which produces the response at a lower dose is more potent than another drug which produces the same response at a higher dose.
  •  Efficacy – It is the maximum response produced by a drug. The maximum height of the curve corresponds to the efficacy, or in other words, the more the height of the curve, the more efficacious that drug becomes.
  •  Safety – The slope of the curve is related to the safety of the drug. The drug with a steeper slope is less safe than a drug with a flatter slope.

In the given graph:

 

Potency: D > A > B > C

 

Efficacy: A = B > C = D

 

Other options:

 

a. The efficacy of both drugs A and B are equal and the efficacy of drugs D and C are equal.

 

b. Drug D is the most potent drug

 

c. Drug C is less potent but equally efficacious to drug D

questions.text: A patient presents with frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis. 24-hour urine volume was measured and recorded to be 7 liters. The urine osmolarity was 260 mOsm/L. ADH assay was performed and the recorded values were reported as 0.8 pg/mL. An MRI of the brain was performed and T1 weighted indicated the absence of the bright spot. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pituitary DI

 

Polyuria and Polydipsia along with absent bright spot on T1-MRI is suggestive of Pituitary Diabetes insipidus.

 

Approach to Polyuria:

  • Water vs solute diuresis: (first thing to know)
  • Water diuresis: DI, Primary polydipsia
  • Solute diuresis:
    • Glycosuria (Hyperglycemia, SGLT2 inhibitor use)
    • Iatrogenic hyper-osmolar agents (Hypertonic saline, Mannitol, Urea - from high-protein tube feeding, Radiocontrast agents)
    • Salt wasting (e.g., Medullary cystic disease, Diuretics, CSWS, Obstructive uropathy -especially if B/L, resolving ATN)

 

MMS algorithm for finding out the cause:

 

 

  • Before giving desmopressin → S. Na+ should be 145(or) P. Osm should be > 295.
  • If this cannot be achieved (usually due to severe thirst) during water deprivation - Alternative for water deprivation is Hypertonic saline infusion to achieve S. Na > 145 or P. Osm > 295 - then desmopressin test can be performed.
  • Hypertonic saline (to ↑P. Osm) + Plasma AVP measurement in response to ↑ P. Osm due to hypertonic saline. Plasma AVP is unstable and needs stringent storage techniques. Based on AVP levels - can diagnose pituitary vs nephrogenic vs primary polydipsia. Diagnostic accuracy is questionable.

**Plasma Co-Peptin (analogues to C-peptide of insulin) can be used for central vs nephrogenic DI.

questions.text: A farmer presents to the emergency department with pinpoint pupil, diarrhea, sweating, excessive lacrimation, salivation and garlic odour. On examination there is bradycardia and BP is 80/60 mm Hg pulse rate is 56/min and his plasma cholinesterase level was 52 U/mL. Which of the following is antidote for treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atropine

 

The clinical scenario of a farmer presenting with increased secretions is suggestive of Organophosphorus poisoning. The antidote for the Organophosphates poisoning is IV Atropine.

 

Organophosphates causes irreversible inhibition of acetylcholinesterase enzyme which leads to raised Acetylcholine levels and so cholinergic side effects (DUMBELSS).

 

The cholinergic side effects include –

Diarrhea

Urination

Miosis

Bradycardia, bronchospasm

Emesis

Lacrimation

Salivation

Sweating


Atropine is repeated every 5 minutes until the signs of Atropinization are seen. These include mydriasis, decrease in secretions, tachycardia. The most common sign is mydriasis whereas the most reliable/specific sign is decreased secretions. Atropine can reverse all the symptoms except for muscle weakness.

 

Pralidoxime, a cholinesterase reactivator can also be used for treatment.


Option A: - Flumazenil is the antidote of choice for benzodiazepine poisoning

 

Option D: - N-acetylcysteine is the antidote of choice for paracetamol poisoning

 

Option C: - Epinephrine is the drug of choice for treating allergic reactions and anaphylaxis and also as a vasoconstrictor.

choices.text: Police not under rank of sub inspector

questions.text: In the civil negligence case against a doctor who bears the onus of proof?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Patient

 

“Onus of proof” implies the responsibility to prove or disprove a crime.

 

As a general rule, the onus to proof lies with the victim (or his lawyer), and not with the accused, in both civil and criminal cases. The accused is assumed to be innocent. It is the responsibility of victim (or his lawyer) to prove that accused has done a crime

 

In criminal case, the burden of proof is always on the state (i.e., the public prosecutor, the government lawyer for victim). The state must prove that the accused is guilty.

 

In civil case, the burden of proof lies on the plaintiff. The plaintiff is a person who brings a case against another in a civil court. The person against whom the case is filed is called defendant. For e.g. in a medical negligence case, the patient is the plaintiff and the doctor is the defendant. Ordinarily the patient (and his lawyer) has to prove that the Doctor is negligent.  

 

Exceptions where onus of proof lies with accused:

  • RES IPSA LOQUITOR (the thing or action speaks of itself)
  • Insanity: If the defendant wishes to claim that he/she is insane, and therefore not guilty, the defendant bears the burden of proving his/her insanity.
  • 114-A CrPc: In a case of rape, where sexual intercourse by the accused is proved and the question is whether it was without the consent of the woman alleged to have been raped, the court shall presume that she did not consent. The accused will have to prove that it was with consent.
  • Contributory Negligence: If a doctor wants to take the defence of contributory negligence, then he will have to prove that the patient was also negligent along with him.

questions.text: A chest X-ray showing a child with a widened mediastinum and a loss of the aortic knob. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the image findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Aortic Coarctation

 

The image shows a widened mediastinum and a loss of the aortic knob, which are indicative of aortic coarctation. This congenital heart defect involves a narrowing of the aorta, leading to increased blood pressure in the upper body and decreased blood pressure in the lower body. This can result in the classic "3 sign" appearance on X-ray and inferior rib notching due to collaterals forming around the narrowed segment.

 

The other options (A, B, and D) do not match the radiological findings.

 

The patient with Pneumonia can have consolidation or bilateral diffuse infiltrates on x-ray chest.


Bronchiolitis is characterised by hyperinflation & patchy bilateral consolidation.
 

Pulmonary hypertension is associated with Jug-handle sign on X-ray.

questions.text: The observed myocardial stunning pattern does not match the ECG findings of a patient. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

 

 

Stress cardiomyopathy commonly affects Women (post-menopausal) > men predominantly due to emotional > physical stress. Neurogenic myocardial stunning occurs leading to heart failure.

 

Beta-2 (Gs stimulation) is present at base and b2 (Gi) activation leads to hypercontractility at the base & apical ballooning giving a typical Takotsubo appearance.

 

ECG mimics ACS, RWMA not corresponding to single artery territory, normal CAG with Mild troponin elevation are clues to takotsubo.

 

Treatment with beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors if non-responsive. Carries good prognosis.

 

 

Other options:

  • Option B - Restrictive cardiomyopathy causes diastolic dysfunction on but NOT significant ECG changes.
  • Option C - Brugada syndrome is a channelopathy caused due to loss of function mutation of cardiac SCN5A (Sodium channel) resulting in transmural voltage difference between endocardium-epicardium causing ventricular arrhythmias which initially affects the RV myocardium.

  • Option D - Tamponade occurs due to rapid accumulation of fluid/blood in the pericardium producing the characteristic Beck triad (raised JVP muffled Heart sounds & hypotension).

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/Cardiomyopathies/Chap 259.

questions.text: According to the WHO, what percentage of immunization coverage is needed for eradication of measles?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 96%


According to the WHO, eradication of measles requires achieving an immunization coverage of at least 96% of children under 1 year of age.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient arrives at the clinic reporting an intense, pulsating headache on one side of their head, accompanied by sensitivity to light and excessive tearing from the affected eye. The patient also mentions experiencing sharp pain on one side of their face when clenching their teeth. During the examination, you observe that the pupillary, light, and accommodation reflexes are functioning normally. Which of the labelled nerves in the provided image is likely to be implicated in this clinical scenario, contributing to the described symptoms and findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3

 

The above patient presents with features suggesting an involvement of the trigeminal nerve. The structure marked 3 is the trigeminal nerve.

 

The various clinical features associated with trigeminal nerve injury are:

  1. Facial pain: Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by severe facial pain, often described as sharp, stabbing, or electric shock-like sensations. The pain is typically triggered by routine activities such as eating, talking, or touching specific areas of the face.
  2. Sensory abnormalities: The trigeminal nerve carries sensory information from the face, including touch, temperature, and pain. When affected, sensory abnormalities may manifest as numbness, tingling, or altered sensation in the face. The distribution of these sensory disturbances depends on which branches of the trigeminal nerve are involved.
  3. Facial muscle weakness: The trigeminal nerve also supplies motor fibers to the muscles involved in chewing, such as the muscles of mastication. In certain conditions, such as trigeminal neuropathy or facial nerve palsy involving the trigeminal nerve, weakness or paralysis of these muscles can occur, leading to difficulty in chewing and controlling facial expressions.
  4. Corneal reflex abnormalities: The ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve is responsible for the corneal reflex, which involves blinking in response to corneal stimulation. Disorders affecting the trigeminal nerve may result in a diminished or absent corneal reflex on the affected side.
  5. Headache: Some disorders involving the trigeminal nerve, such as trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (e.g., cluster headaches), can cause severe headaches on one side of the head. These headaches often occur in close proximity to the trigeminal nerve distribution.

 

Other marked structures:

 

1- Optic nerve

 

2- Abducent nerve

 

4- Vestibulo cochlear nerve
