questions.text: At what age does the anterior fontanelle usually close in a typically developing infant?
questions.solution:

The anterior fontanelle, a soft spot on the baby's head, typically closes around 8-18 months of age. This process is part of normal growth and development.

 

Options A, B, and D are not accurate time frames for the closure of the anterior fontanelle.

  • Anterior fontanelle fuses at around the age of 18-24 months to become bregma.
  • Posterior fontanelle fuses at 3 months of age to become lambda.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a unilateral throbbing headache associated with nausea and vomiting. Which of the following drugs can be used to prevent these episodes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Propranolol

 

The given clinical history of the young female with unilateral throbbing headaches which are associated with nausea and vomiting and increases on exposure to bright light is suggestive of Migraine. To relieve her episodes, the best drug out of the given options is Propranolol.

Other Options:

Option C) Diazepam: It is also a benzodiazepine which has similar action as Alprazolam and so is not used in management of patients with Migraine.

 

Option D) Fluoxetine: It is an antidepressant belonging to the class of drugs known as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs). It is primarily prescribed to treat major depressive disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, panic disorder, and other mood disorders. It is not indicated in Migraine.

questions.text: In a particular community, the usual number of reported dengue cases ranges from 40 to 50 per week. However, this week, there were 48 reported cases. How would this situation be classified?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endemic

 

The given scenario is an example of an endemic disease.

 

Endemic diseases are those that have a constant presence and /or usual prevalence of a disease or infectious agent in a population within a geographic area.

 

Epidemic refers to an increase, often sudden, in the number of cases of a disease above what is normally expected in that population in that area.

 

Pandemic refers to the occurrence of a disease which affects exceptionally high proportion of the population across international boundaries.

 

Sporadic diseases occur in a haphazard and irregular manner from time to time.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease presents to the emergency room with complaints of shortness of breath and chest pain. On physical examination, his vital signs are stable, but he appears to be in respiratory distress. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows low voltage QRS complexes and electrical alternans. CXR was performed which is shown here. What is the likely finding on auscultation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pericardial friction rub

 

Dyspnea and Chest pain along with low voltage ECG with the enlarged cardiac shadow is suggestive of pericardial effusion. The x-ray appearance shown is known as money bag appearance. A friction rub is caused by the inflamed layers of the pericardium rubbing against each other during cardiac contraction and relaxation.

 

B. Dull note on right lower chest - Pleural effusion, which is an accumulation of fluid in the pleural space. The dullness on percussion is due to the fluid present in the pleural space.

 

C. Ellis S curve – Rising note of dullness laterally in pleural effusion

 

D. Hyper-resonant note on right lower chest - Pneumothorax, which is the presence of air in the pleural space. The hyper-resonance on percussion is due to the increased amount of air present in the pleural space.

 

 

Reference - Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 36

questions.text: In a case involving a 34-year-old man with fever and significant splenomegaly, the spleen was found to measure 15 cm and displayed an oblique orientation when assessed from the right iliac fossa. What anatomical structure serves to hinder the spleen's direct downward and vertical displacement?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Phrenicocolic ligament

  • The downward movement of the spleen is naturally prevented by the phrenicocolic ligament, which does not attach to the spleen itself but supports its anterior end.
  • This ligament is a horizontal fold of peritoneum that extends from the splenic flexure of the colon to the diaphragm, opposite of the 11th rib in the midaxillary line. The phrenicocolic ligament also limits the upper end of the left paracolic gutter.
  • In cases where the spleen becomes enlarged, the phrenicocolic ligament and splenic flexure of the colon restrict its downward displacement. This enlargement typically occurs towards the right iliac fossa, causing the spleen to be directed obliquely.
  • By supporting the anterior end of the spleen, the phrenicocolic ligament plays an important role in preventing its excessive movement and displacement within the abdominal cavity.

questions.text: A drug is launched in the market for post-marketing surveillance after which of the following phases of the clinical trials?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Phase 3

 

Phase 3 of a clinical trial is often referred to as an efficacy trial. It is after this phase that the drug is launched in the market for post-marketing surveillance of the long term and rare side effects.

 

Phases of Clinical Trials:

 

Phase 1 trials are typically the first-in-human studies and are designed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of the investigational drug or intervention.

 

Phase 2 trials are designed to evaluate the safety and preliminary efficacy of the investigational drug or intervention in a larger patient population than in phase 1 trials.

 

Phase 3 trials are designed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of the investigational drug or intervention in a larger and more diverse patient population. Phase 3 trials typically involve several hundred to several thousand participants and are usually randomized, controlled trials that compare the investigational drug or intervention to either a placebo or an active comparator.

 

Phase 4 trials, also known as post-marketing surveillance studies, are conducted after a drug or intervention has been approved by regulatory agencies and are designed to monitor the long-term safety and effectiveness of the drug or intervention in a larger patient population than in earlier phases of the trial.

  • ﻿﻿Intestinal Anthrax - Hemorrhagic diarrhoea. It occurs mainly in primitive communities that eat the carcasses of animals dying of anthrax.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient, who was diagnosed with Type-2 Diabetes mellitus 4 years ago, had been non-compliant with his medications. He has come to the OPD with the complaints of reduced urine output, leg swelling, weakness. Urine examination reveals proteinuria and his Blood pressure is 180/110 mmHg. Biopsy of one of his Kidneys reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Diabetic Nephropathy

 

The clinical history of the patient with Diabetes Mellitus type-2 being non-compliant with his medications, having proteinuria and hypertension is suggestive of Diabetic nephropathy. The biopsy image shows Kimmelsteil Wilson nodules which are pathognomic of the disease.

 

Diabetic nephropathy is a progressive kidney disease that occurs as a complication of diabetes mellitus. It is one of the most common and serious microvascular complications of diabetes and a leading cause of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) worldwide. Diabetic nephropathy affects both type 1 and type 2 diabetes patients and is characterized by structural and functional changes in the kidneys.

 

Clinical Features:

Proteinuria: earliest feature is microalbuminuria

Hypertension

Edema

Decline in Kidney Function

 

Diagnosis:

Urine Albumin-to-Creatinine Ratio (UACR)

Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR)

 

Management:

Glycemic Control

Blood Pressure Control: ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are commonly prescribed to protect the kidneys and reduce proteinuria.

Protein Restriction

Regular Follow-up: Regular monitoring of kidney function, blood pressure, and urine albumin levels is crucial for disease management and early detection of any changes.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of acute bronchiolitis in infants and young children?

While the other viruses listed can also cause respiratory infections, RSV is particularly known for causing bronchiolitis in this age group.

  • Medial two lumbricals are bipennate and originate from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons associated with the middle and ring fingers and the ring and little fingers, respectively; Supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve.
  • Lateral two lumbricals are unipennate muscles, originating from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons associated with index and middle fingers, respectively; Supplied by digital branches of the median nerve.

questions.text: A patient suffered from tibial fracture following a road traffic accident. He complained of pain on passive flexion of the knee. His posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses were palpable. He had loss of sensation in the 1st web space. What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Measure anterior compartment pressure

 

Compartment Syndrome

  • In acute compartment syndrome, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly, compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common causes: fractures and dislocations
  • Other causes:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intra-compartmental pressure and muscle edema

Clinical Features

  • The diagnosis is made by dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) that is not even getting relieved on analgesics.
  • Pain and resistance on passive stretch of the distal most joint of extremity (1st sign).
  • The order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intra-compartmental pressure is: capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
  • Pulselessness is a late feature and is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome. The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
  • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
  • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated as compared to the pressures in other compartments. Deep flexor muscles are involved, particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.

Treatment:

  • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
  • Removal of all circumferential dressing & reduce pressure up to 85%.
  • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm.
  • The morbidity caused by fasciotomy is minimal, whereas that caused by an untreated compartment syndrome is much greater.
  • The general indications for fasciotomy are impending tissue ischemia or it may be considered when the tissue pressure reaches 30 mmHg or the difference between diastolic blood pressure and compartment pressure is < 30 mmHg.

(Normal compartment pressure is 8-10 mmHg and pressure at calf during walking is 200-300 mmHg).

  • A higher pressure is a strong indication that fasciotomy should be recommended.
  • In a hypotensive patient, the acceptable pressure is lower.
  • Mubarak recommended that fasciotomy be performed in:
    1. Normotensive patients with positive clinical findings, compartment pressures of > 30 mmHg, and when the duration of the increased pressure is unknown or thought to be longer than 8 hours
    2. Uncooperative/unconscious patients with a compartment pressure > 30 mmHg
    3. Patients with low blood pressure and a compartment pressure > 20 mmHg
    4. Clinical signs such as demonstrable motor or sensory loss
    5. Interrupted arterial circulation to the extremity for > 4 hours

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presents to the surgical clinic with a history of severe abdominal pain, recurrent episodes of intestinal obstruction, and unintentional weight loss over the past few months. The patient has a known history of Crohn's disease, which has been managed with medications over the last 10 years. However, the condition recently exacerbated, leading to multiple episodes of bowel obstruction refractory to conservative management. Due to the progressive nature of the disease and unresponsive symptoms, surgical intervention was deemed necessary. Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Normal gastric secretions contain a glycoprotein called intrinsic factor, secreted by the same parietal cells that secrete hydrochloric acid. Intrinsic factor must be present for adequate absorption of vitamin B12 from the ileum. That is, intrinsic factor combines with vitamin B12 in the stomach and protects it from being digested and destroyed as it passes into the small intestine. Then, when the intrinsic factor–vitamin B12 complex reaches the terminal ileum, the intrinsic factor binds with receptors on the ileal epithelial surface. This in turn makes it possible for the vitamin B12 to be absorbed.

 

Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

  • Iron is absorbed in duodenum and upper jejunum
  • Folate is absorbed in jejunum
  • Vitamin B12 is absorbed in terminal Ileum

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presented to the Gynaecology OPD with itching over vulva and thick greenish discharge per vaginum. Per speculum examination reveals Strawberry Cervix for which she was prescribed Metronidazole. Which of the following substances should she not take while on the treatment with this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Alcohol

 

Metronidazole can lead to Disulfiram like reactions, when taken with alcohol. Disulfiram is an aversive drug, that inhibits the aldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to accumulation of acetaldehyde in the body, which can lead to symptoms like throbbing headache, flushing, chest tightness, visual disturbances, nausea etc. Hence these symptoms prevent the patient from taking alcohol.

 

Drugs like Metronidazole, Sulfonylureas and Cefoperazone can also lead to similar symptoms if taken in the presence of alcohol.

 

Drugs associated with Disulfiram Like Reaction:

  • Metronidazole
  • Sulfonylurea
  • Cefoperazone
  • Chlorpropamide
  • Griseofulvin
  • Procarbazine

Left ear audiogram is plotted with blue ink and right ear audiogram is plotted with red ink. (RR – Right Red).

 

Whenever a PTA is given, first see whether there is air-bone gap (AC & BC curves are separated by a long gap or not?)

  1. If there is no air-bone gap or very less gap, then it could be sensorineural hearing loss.
  • Then search in the options for the conditions that cause sensorineural hearing loss (Meniere’s – B/L, acoustic neuroma – U/L, Noise induced hearing loss – B/L, presbycusis – B/L).
  1. If there is a long separation in between the AC & BC curves, then it could be either conductive or mixed.
  • First see the distantly separated curves are in the upper part of the graph or lower part. If occupying upper part, then it is conductive hearing loss and if occupying lower part, then it could be mixed.

Accordingly search for the conditions that cause such type of hearing loss in the given options.

questions.text: A female patient presents with concerns of discomfort and inflammation in the perineal region, accompanied by difficulties while walking and sitting. She discloses a past medical history involving multiple sexual partners. Upon examination, a tender swelling is observed, displaying redness on the labia, as depicted in the provided image. What is the probable diagnosis for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bartholin abscess

 

The given clinical scenario and image points to the diagnosis of Bartholin's abscess.

 

Bartholin gland:

 

Bartholin gland is a mucus-secreting gland, which plays a role in vaginal lubrication. They are a pair of 0.5 cm glands located in the lower right and left portions at the 4 o’clock and 8 o’clock positions of the vaginal introitus. They are generally non-palpable when not obstructed.

 

BARTHOLIN CYST AND ABSCESS

 

Pathophysiology:

 

Bartholin glands can form a cyst and an abscess in women of reproductive age and may cause dyspareunia, urinary irritation, and vague pelvic pain.

 

Clinical features:

  • The physical exam will often reveal asymmetry with a protrusion of one side (left or right) of the inferior aspect of the vulva.
  • Bartholin gland abscesses, unlike Bartholin cysts, are very painful.
  • While both are primarily unilateral, Bartholin abscesses are often tender to palpation, erythematous, indurated, and may have an area of fluctuance and/or purulent drainage.

Treatment:

  • Asymptomatic Bartholin cysts do not require further treatment.
  • Bartholin abscesses may be treated with incision and drainage with Word catheter placement due to ease and effectiveness of treatment.
  • Marsupialization is the procedure of choice.
  • Women with recurrent cysts or those who are post-menopausal (risk of malignancy) should have the cyst completely excised.

 

About other options:

  • Option A - Chlamydial infection patient usually present with vaginal discharge, dysuria, or cervicitis.
  • Option C - Genital tuberculosis involves the upper genital tract, leading to menstrual irregularities, infertility, and abdominal pain.
  • Option D - Genital herpes usually presents as painful ulcers or vesicles in the genital area, rather than a tender, erythematous swelling.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of multiple sexual partners presents with lower abdominal pain for 1 month. Additionally, she has reported experiencing minimal discharge and intermenstrual bleeding. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Neisseria gonorrhoea

 

The history of multiple sexual partners and lower abdominal pain with discharge and intermenstrual bleed suggests a diagnosis of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease, of which cause can be N. Gonorrhoea among the given options.

 

Treatment:

 

KIT 6 (Yellow) 

 

Tab Cefixime 400 mg 1 Tab

 

Tab Metronidazole 400 mg (1 tab BD x 1 days)

 

 Tab Doxycycline 100 mg (1 tab BD x 21 days)

 

 

 

About other options:

  • Option A - Herpes simplex causes painful genital ulcers.
  • Option B - Genital tuberculosis is seen in sexually inactive females
  • Option C - Vaginal candidiasis presents as intense pruritus and white discharge.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with lesion in tibial diaphysis. Histopathological examination is shown in below given image. On IHC, it was MIC-2 positive and synaptophysin positive cells. Most likely diagnosis will be?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ewing sarcoma

 

EWING SARCOMA

 

Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life.

 

Ewing’s sarcoma

 

Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients with Ewing sarcoma.

 

In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling suggesting osteomyelitis. Laboratory studies may reveal an increased white blood cell count, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and an elevated C-reactive protein.

 

To complicate matters further, a needle aspirate of Ewing sarcoma may grossly resemble pus, and the tissue may be sent in its entirety to microbiology and none to pathology. (As a general rule, most biopsy specimens should be sent for culture and pathological analysis.)

 

Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. In reality, Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. MRI of the entire bone should be ordered to evaluate the full extent of the lesion, which typically extends beyond the abnormality apparent on plain films.

 

MRI also is useful to evaluate the extent of the soft-tissue mass, which often is very large. All patients should have a baseline radiograph and a CT scan of the chest because the lung is the most common site of metastases.

 

A bone scan should be performed because bone is the second most common site of metastases. In contrast to other bone sarcomas, a bone marrow aspirate should be obtained as a routine part of the staging of Ewing sarcoma to rule out diffuse systemic disease.

 

Ewing's sarcoma is part of a family of peripheral neuroectodermal tumors (PNET) that share a common cytogenetic translocation of chromosomes 11 and 22, t(11:22), differing only in their degree of neural differentiation, Ewing’s sarcoma is poorly differentiated whereas PNET exhibits definite neural differentiation. (N myc positive).

 

The t(11; 22) (q24; q12) is the most common translocation diagnostic of Ewing sarcoma and is present in greater than 90% of cases. Other diagnostic translocations, including t(21; 22) (q22; q12), t(7; 22) (p22; q12), trisomy 8 and trisomy 12.

 

Mic 2(CD99) is a specific marker for Ewing's sarcoma and peripheral primitive neuroectodermal tumors and is expressed on short-arm of chromosome x and y. In addition, Ewing sarcomas usually are periodic acid–Schiff positive (owing to intracellular glycogen) and reticulin negative.

 

Note: Contrast to lymphomas, which are periodic acid–Schiff negative and reticulin positive.

choices.text: Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman arrives at the infertility clinic with her mother-in-law. Despite engaging in regular intercourse for the past 6 months, she has been unable to conceive. What would be the most appropriate course of action going forward?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Reassure and review the couple after 6 months

 

The next best step would be to reassure and review the couple after 6 months since female is <35 years old and investigations are not indicated.

 

Infertility is defined as inability of a couple to conceive after 1 year of unprotected intercourse.

  • If age of a female is <35 years, begin investigations after 1 year.
  • If age of a female is >35 years, begin investigations after 6 months.
  • If age of a female is ≥40 years, begin investigations after 3 months.

Investigations include:

  1. Semen analysis
  2. Ovulation and evaluation for the diminished ovarian reserve
  3. Evaluation of Female reproductive tract abnormality

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric OPD by his parents with complaints of headache, vomiting, dizziness and unsteady gait for the past 2 months. What is the likely grade of the tumor on the basis of the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Grade 4

 

The MRI results point to an enhancing lesion in the 4th ventricle, likely to be a medulloblastoma. It is the most common malignant brain tumor in children, and it only occurs in the cerebellum. Medulloblastomas correspond histologically to WHO grade IV tumors, regardless of their histological or genetic characterization.

 

Radiological findings include:

  • CT - Hyperdense midline vermian mass adjoining the roof of the 4th ventricle and causing hydrocephalus.
  • MRI - T2 hypo-intensity
  • DWI - Restricted diffusion

 

 

Reference – Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 726.

Occult blood test on his stool sample is positive. Colonoscopic biopsy of the patient reveals the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place
Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained
Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place
Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary.

questions.text: After fitting the pessary, what is the initial step to ensure proper retention of the pessary?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place

  • Generally, a patient is fitted with a pessary while in the lithotomy position after she has emptied both her bladder and rectum.
  • A digital examination is performed to assess vaginal length and width, and an initial estimation of pessary size is made.
  • Lubricant is placed on either the vaginal introitus or the pessary’s leading edge.
  • While holding the labia apart, the pessary is inserted by pushing in a cephalad direction and against the posterior vaginal wall.
  • Next, an index finger is directed into the posterior vaginal fornix to ensure that the cervix is resting above the pessary.
  • The clinician’s finger should barely slide between the lateral edges of the ring pessary and the vaginal sidewall.
  • The pessary should fit snugly but not tightly against the symphysis pubis and the posterior and lateral vaginal walls.
  • Too much pressure may increase the risk or pain.

Following pessary placement:

  • Woman is prompted to perform a Valsalva maneuver, which might dislodge an improperly fitted pessary.
  • She should be able to stand, walk, cough, and urinate without difficulty or discomfort.
  • Instruction on removal and placement then follows.
  • After initial placement, a return visit may follow in 1 to 2 weeks.
  • If the patient and the provider are motivated, most women can be taught to self-manage a pessary.
  • For those unable or unwilling to remove and replace a device themselves, a pessary may be removed, and the patient’s vagina inspected at the OPD every 2 or 3 months.
  • Delaying visits longer than this may lead to vaginal infection.

questions.text: A middle-aged man is diagnosed with mucopolysaccharidosis with accumulation of a specific type of glycosaminoglycans, which determines the charge selectiveness of renal glomerular membrane. Which GAG that could be?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Heparan sulphate            

  • It has a disaccharide unit: Glucosamine and glucuronic or iduronic acid. Some Glucosamines are acetylated and few are sulphated.
  • Heparan sulphate is extracellular and associated with the plasma membrane of cells, with their core proteins spanning the membrane.
  • They act as receptors and participate in cell growth, cell-cell communication, attachment of cells to their substratum in the culture medium.
  • It is seen in the basement membrane of the kidney with type IV collagen and laminin and plays a major role in determining the charge selectiveness of glomerular filtration.

Incorrect answers:

  • False: Option (B) Dermatan sulphate: Found in skin, blood vessels and heart valves and determines the elasticity of heart valve and skin.
  • False: Option (C) Hyaluronic acid: Present in connective tissues, tendons, synovial fluid and vitreous humor and acts as a lubricant and shock absorber in joint cavities.
  • False: Option (D) Keratan sulphate: Only GAG, which does not contain uronic acid and found in cornea and tendons, thereby maintaining corneal transparency.

The vital of the patient is unstable and bedside echocardiography reveals enlarged heart chambers and reduced wall thickness with reduced contractility of the heart. Which of the following will be the histopathological findings in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ninja star appearance of the nuclei of cardiac myocytes

 

Alcoholic male patient with atrial fibrillation and echo findings are suggestive of Dilated cardiomyopathy. On Histopathological examination, Ninja star appearance of the nucleus of the cardiac myocytes is seen.

 

 

Other Options:

  • Option A and C - Haphazard arrangement of myocardial fibres is seen in Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Hypertrophy of cardiac myocytes of the interventricular septum is also a feature of HCM.

  • Option C - Extracellular amyloid deposition with extensive fibrosis is seen in Restrictive cardiomyopathy. It is more common with Amyloidosis, Sarcoidosis, Hemochromatosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to the gastroenterology clinic with a history of bloody diarrhea and abdominal cramps for the past 2 weeks. She has been experiencing increased frequency of bowel movements with a sense of incomplete evacuation. The patient reports feeling fatigued and has lost a significant amount of weight over the past few months. On examination, the patient appears pale and there is tenderness over the left lower quadrant of the abdomen. A colonoscopy is performed and reveals evidence of inflammation in the mucosal layer of the colon, with friability, erythema, and mucosal ulcerations extending proximally from the rectum. What earliest sign seen on Barium study in the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Mucosal Granularity

 

The given clinical scenario, having mucosal inflammation and ulceration which involves rectum, points towards the diagnosis of Ulcerative colitis.

 

  • Continuous involvement of colon (mucosal /submucosal involvement)-Loss of haustrations called lead pipe colon.
  • Earliest sign on barium: Diffuse mucosal granularity.

choices.text: Threshold point is at A
At point E, the nerve is more excitable
Point C to D is due to opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels
Point B to D is refractory period

questions.text: What can be said about the provided nerve action potential curve is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Point B to D is refractory period

 

The correct statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is point B to D is the refractory period.

 

 

Inference:

  • At point 1 - Resting membrane potential: Membrane is more permeable to K+ than Na+ at rest. Voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels are closed.
  • At point 2 - Membrane depolarization: Na+ activation gate opens → Na+ flows inward.
  • At point 3 - Membrane repolarization: Na+ inactivation gate closes at peak potential, thus stopping Na+ inflow. K+ activation gate opens → K+ flows outward.
  • At point 4 - Membrane hyperpolarization: K+ activation gates are slow to close → excess K+ efflux and brief period of hyperpolarization. Voltage-gated Na+ channels switch back to resting state. Na+/K+ pump restores ions concentration.

Refractory period:

  • Point 2 to 4 is a part of the refractory period. During this period, the application of even a stronger stimulus will not elicit an action potential.
  • The refractory period is divided into two:
    1. Absolute refractory period - During the absolute refractory period, the nerve will not be excited no matter how strong a stimulus is given.
    2. Relative refractory period - During the relative refractory period, stronger than normal stimuli can cause excitation.

questions.text: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fluent aphasia

 

Regions anterior to the central sulcus are motor areas and posterior are sensory areas. Hence temporal gyrus involvement causes a fluent aphasia.

 

 

Reference - KV Krishna Das textbook of Medicine 5th edition

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Circumvallate

  • The given histological image is a section of the tongue displaying circumvallate papillae, which are the largest papillae present on the tongue.
  • They are cylindrical in shape, and usually around 8-12 in no.
  • They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and are arranged in a V-shaped row immediately in front of the sulcus terminalis on the dorsal surface of the tongue.
  • They are narrower at their base than their apex and contain numerous taste buds (around 250 for each papilla) within their walls. These taste buds contain chemosensory cells that synapse with the gustatory nerves, enabling the sense of taste.
  • In addition, the serous glands of Von Ebner empty via ducts into the base of the sulcus, which helps to flush out food particles from the area surrounding the papillae.

 

Other options:

  • Option A: Fungiform papillae are protrusions on the tongue that are relatively large, round, and reddish in color. They can be found on both the dorsal surface and the lingual margins of the tongue, and are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Option C: Filiform papillae are small, conical or cylindrical projections located mainly on the dorsal surface of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. They lack taste buds and are covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. All other papillae, except filiform, contain taste buds.
  • Option D: Foliate papillae are red, leaf-like mucosal ridges located bilaterally in two zones at the sides of the tongue near the sulcus terminalis. They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

questions.text: A diabetic truck driver presents to you with cough and breathlessness. A diagnosis of pneumonia was confirmed, and histopathological examination revealed dichotomous branching, as shown below. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Aspergillus

  • The most likely causative agent based on the clinical features and image showing dichotomous branching at acute angles given is Aspergillus.
  • Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients.
  • Voriconazole is the drug of choice.
  • Histopathological examination of the tissue section shows characteristic dichotomous branching at an acute angle.

Other options:

  • Options A and B - Rhizopus and Mucor are zygomycetes that are responsible for mucormycosis. Non-septate, broad hyphae are seen on tissue samples stained with hematoxylin and eosin.
  • Option C - Candida, the causative agent for candidiasis, appear as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida is in labor. She is presenting with a recurring need to urinate and experiencing premature bearing down. During examination, infra-umbilical flattening is observed, and the fetal heart sounds are heard on the lateral side. What is the most probable presentation/position of the fetus in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Occipito-posterior

 

Diagnosis - Occipito-Posterior Position

  • History
    • Early rupture of membranes.
    • Frequent filling of bladder.
    • Premature bearing down.
       
  • Abdominal Exam
    • Inspection: infra-umbilical flattening.
    • Grips: Head not engaged.
    • Auscultation: FHS – flanks.
       
  • Vaginal Exam
    • Elongated bag of membranes.
    • Posterior fontanelle is near the sacro-iliac joint.
    • Anterior fontanelle is felt more easily because of deflexion.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male is diagnosed with duodenal ulcer and exploring surgical options for his treatment. Which of the surgical options listed below has highest patient tolerance in the management of the ulcers?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Highly selective vagotomy

 

Highly selective vagotomy is most well tolerated procedure with limited side effect profile.

 

HIGHLY SELECTIVE VAGOTOMY

    • Only denervate individual branches of the anterior and posterior vagus.
    • Preserve the crow's feet (last 6 cm over pylorus).
    • Hence preserving the innervation of pylorus (last 6 cm) → Pylorus will relax → Hence, no need for a drainage procedure.
    • Best tolerated acid lowering procedure → Fairly good ulcer healing procedure.

Recurrence rates after surgery for duodenal ulcer:

  1. Truncal vagotomy with pyloroplasty - 2 to 7%
  2. Selective vagotomy with pyloroplasty - 5 to 10%
  3. Highly selective Vagotomy - 2 to 10%
  4. Truncal vagotomy with antrectomy - 1%

choices.text: Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida visits the healthcare facility at 36 weeks of gestation, complaining of painful ulcers on her vulva. She denies having experienced any similar lesions in the past. During the examination, multiple painful vesicular lesions are observed. What would be the most appropriate course of treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

  • The diagnosis in this woman is genital herpes simplex (HSV).
  • Since she has never had similar lesions in the past, this is primary genital herpes.
  • The risk of neonatal infection following vaginal delivery with primary HSV is very high (up to 50%). Neonatal herpes has a very high mortality rate.
  • Antivirals (Acyclovir) have to be started.
  • Hence the recommended mode of delivery in primary HSV is elective cesarean section.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a past history of visceral leishmaniasis presents to the dermatology clinic with multiple hypopigmented macules on his face, arms, and trunk. He reports that the skin lesions began appearing several months after his leishmaniasis was successfully treated. He denies any other associated symptoms, and there is no sensory loss or nerve thickening noted upon examination. A diagnosis of post kala azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL) is considered, what is the important differential diagnosis for PKDL among the below options?

Post kala azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL) is a complication of visceral leishmaniasis and PKDL is an important D/D of lepromatous leprosy since both the conditions have symmetrical distribution of hypopigmented and nodular lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following local anesthetics causes hypertension?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cocaine

 

Local anaesthetic that causes hypertension is cocaine.

 

Cocaine causes sympathetic stimulation leading to:

  • Tachycardia

  • Coronary vasoconstriction

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 982-983

questions.text: Cancer cells derive nutrition mainly from:
questions.solution:
Ans. A.  Glycolysis

  • In 1924, the biochemist Otto Warburg and his colleagues discovered that cancer cells take up large amounts of glucose and metabolize it to lactic acid, even in the presence of oxygen.
  • This observation is known as the Warburg effect.
  • Based on these data, Warburg made two hypotheses:
    1. The increased ratio of glycolysis to aerobic respiration was due to defects in the mitochondrial respiratory chain
    2. This enhanced glycolysis enabled cancer cells to proliferate in the reduced oxygen tension often seen in tumours.
       
  • Thus, the switching from aerobic to anaerobic glucose metabolism was the driver of tumorigenesis.

Incorrect answers:

 

False: Option (b, c, d) are thus ruled out. 

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p738.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with concerns about warty lesions on her vulva. Upon examination, numerous warty growths are observed on the vulva and surrounding the anal canal, as shown below. Which condition is most commonly associated with these findings?

questions.text: What is the maximum period of voluntary self-admission under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 30 days

 

The maximum period of voluntary self-admission is 30 days.

 

When a person has a mental illness that necessitates admission and is capable of making his or her own decision and voluntarily requests admission, this is referred to as voluntary self-admission.

 

According to the Mental Healthcare Act, the maximum duration for which such admission can last is 30 days. If the admission requires more than 30 days, or if it requires readmission within 7 days after discharge, then such patients should be examined by two psychiatrists and can be admitted for a maximum period of 90 days.

questions.text: According to the berlin definition, moderate ARDS is characterized by all, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. PaO2/FiO2 ratio 200-300 mmHg

 

2012 Berlin Definition:

  1. Onset within 7 days after a known clinical insult or new or worsening respiratory symptoms
  2. B/L opacities (Alveolar/Interstitial that are "consistent with pulmonary edema" on chest radiographs or chest CT)
  3. Minimum PEEP setting or CPAP, 5 cm of water.

PaO2: FiO2 assessed on invasive mechanical ventilation (CPAP criterion used for the diagnosis of mild ARDS).

 

Categorization of ARDS severity (on the basis of FiO2):

  1. Mild: 200-300
  2. Moderate: 100-200
  3. Severe: < 100

In resource limited settings Kigali Modifications was proposed (2016):

  1. Bilateral opacities could be documented by either ultrasonography or chest radiograph.
  2. Oxygenation criteria: pulse oximetry oxygen saturation (SpO2)/FiO2 ratio ≤ 315 without the requirement for PEEP.

Option B, C, and D are true statements in ARDS.

questions.text: You are currently evaluating a multigravida in the second stage of labor, which has been ongoing for the last two hours. During examination, it is noted that contractions are sufficient, and the cervix is fully dilated. The fetal head is at station 0, with moderate molding (2+) and a noticeable swelling on the presenting part (caput) of the head (2+). The sagittal suture is in the right occipito-transverse position. Additionally, the fetal heart rate is recorded 140 beats per minute. Based on this assessment, what course of action should be taken for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lower segment cesarean section

  • The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of deep transverse arrest (DTA).
  • There are features of CPD (Caput 2 + and moulding 2+).
  • Hence, a lower segment cesarean section is carried out for the management of this patient.
  • A vacuum delivery can be attempted in multigravidas with DTA with no CPD.
  • In deep transverse arrest
    • The sagittal suture is placed in the transverse bispinous diameter.
    • There is no descent of the head despite good uterine contractions

questions.text: Which theory explains primary acquired cholesteatoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Wittmaack’s retraction pocket theory

 

There are different theories proposed for cholesteatoma formation –

  1. Wittmaack’s retraction pocket theory (as described below)
  2. Ruedi’s basal cell hyperplasia – basal cells in middle ear lay down keratinising squamous epithelium due to infection
  3. Habermann’s epithelial invasion – epithelium present outside in the external canal invades through marginal perforation of tympanic membrane into middle ear
  4. Sade’s metaplasia theory – middle ear mucosa undergoes metaplasia due to infection and transforms into squamous epithelium of keratinising type.

As a retraction pocket deepens into middle ear, its opening towards external auditory canal becomes narrower and the part in the middle ear bulges like a sac. The keratin produced by the epithelial lining inside gets accumulated and cannot migrate outward. This keratin mass surrounded by its producing epithelium which is in turn surrounded by fibrous stroma of surrounding middle ear part is called as cholesteatoma (it is a misnomer, neither cholesterol is seen nor it is a tumour).

 

A cholesteatoma is nothing but the wrong skin at a wrong place. It is pearly white in colour. Normally, keratinising squamous epithelium should lie in the external auditory canal. But due to any reason, if this epithelium comes to lie in middle ear, then this is called as cholesteatoma. Inside middle ear, it secretes enzymes and destroys the bone it comes in contact with.

 

Different Types of Cholesteatoma –

  1. Congenital cholesteatoma – due to embryologic epidermal cell rests left over in middle ear. Tympanic membrane will be intact. Whitish cotton-wool like mass present behind intact TM on otoscopy, most commonly in antero-superior quadrant.
  2. Primary acquired cholesteatoma – no previous history of ear infections or perforations will be present, like pars flaccida invagination, basal cell hyperplasia, squamous metaplasia. A retraction pocket formation is the main reason in most of the cases, which is due to constant negative pressure in the middle ear, which may be inturn due to eustachian tube block, deviated nasal septum, etc. Wittmaack’s retraction pocket theory explains the same.
  3. Secondary acquired cholesteatoma – here, there will be a pre-existing perforation. Outer squamous epithelium migrates through these perforations (mostly marginal) into middle ear. Habermann’s epithelial invasion theory explains this. 

    Other 2 theories – Sade metaplasia and Ruedi basal cell hyperplasia are not accepted as they cannot explain the exact pathogenesis.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient with a midline neck swelling and histopathological findings of Orphan Annie eye nuclei on biopsy as shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Papillary carcinoma

 

The presence of empty appearing nuclei (Orphan Annie eye nuclei) is diagnostic of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

  • Histological Appearance: Papillary carcinoma has a papillary growth pattern with branching papillae composed of fibrovascular stalks and cuboidal epithelial cells.
  • Orphan Annie Eye Nuclei: Papillary carcinoma cells have distinct Orphan Annie eye nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin and an optically clear or empty appearance.
  • Psammoma Bodies: Papillary carcinoma often contains psammoma bodies, which are concentrically calcified structures found within the papillae.
  • Lymphatic Invasion: Papillary carcinoma commonly exhibits lymphatic invasion; involvement of blood vessels is uncommon.
  • Genetic Alterations: Papillary carcinoma is associated with specific genetic changes, including gene rearrangements like RET/PTC and NTRK1, as well as BRAF gene mutations.

questions.text: From which of the following structures does the labelled A in the provided image originate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Falciform ligament

 

The structure marked A is ventral mesogastrium. The falciform ligament is a derivative of the ventral mesogastrium.

 

 

  • Mesogastrium is double layers of the peritoneum that enclose an organ (stomach) and connect it to the body wall. They provide pathways for vessels, nerves, and lymphatics to and from the abdominal viscera.
  • The ventral mesogastrium: is a structure found only in the foregut and is attached to the terminal part of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper part of the duodenum.
  • It is derived from the septum transversum and is divided into two parts by the growth of the liver into the mesenchyme of the septum transversum.
  • These two parts are the lesser omentum, which extends from the lower portion of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper portion of the duodenum to the liver, and the ligaments of the liver, which include all the liver ligaments except for the ligamentum teres.
  • The Dorsal mesogastrium: The foregut, midgut, and hindgut are connected to the posterior abdominal wall by the Dorsal mesogastrium.
  • The dorsal mesentery extends from the lower end of the esophagus to the cloacal region of the hindgut and has specific names depending on the region it is found in.
    • Dorsal mesogastrium (or greater omentum)- stomach
    • Dorsal mesoduodenum- duodenum
    • Mesentery proper- jejunum and ileum
    • Mesoappendix- appendix
    • Transverse mesocolon- transverse colon

questions.text: A patient with damage to basilar membrane presented with low frequency hearing loss. Where is the location of most likely lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Helicotrema

 

The affected structure in low-frequency hearing loss is the apical turn of the cochlea. Among the given options, the structure that lies near it is the helicotrema.

 

Movements of the stapes footplate, transmitted to the cochlear fluids, move the basilar membrane and set up shearing force between the tectorial membrane and the hair cells. The distortion of hair cells gives rise to cochlear microphonics, which trigger the nerve impulse. A sound wave, depending on its frequency, reaches maximum amplitude on a particular place on the basilar membrane and stimulates that segment (travelling wave theory of von Bekesy).

 

Higher frequencies are represented in the basal turn of the cochlea and the progressively lower ones towards the apex.

questions.text: Match the following drugs based on their mechanism of causing ototoxicity.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. a-3, b-1, c-2

 

Stria vascularis in Scala media secretes endolymph. Ototoxic drugs like furosemide, bumetanide, ethacrynic acid cause oedema & cystic changes in stria vascularis causing hearing impairment. Quinine & chloroquine/hydroxychloroquine ototoxicity is due to vasoconstriction in the small vessels of stria vascularis.

 

Outer hair cells and inner hair cells are present in organ of corti. These have small hair like stereocilia above their surfaces. They rub against the tectorial membrane above when basilar membrane moves in response to fluid vibrations set-up during sound conduction.

 

Aminoglycosides like neomycin, kanamycin, amikacin, sisomycin, dihydro-streptomycin and cytotoxic drugs like nitrogen mustard, cisplatin, carboplatin damage outer hair cells causing hearing impairment (cochleotoxic).

 

Type 1 hair cells in the vestibule (saccule and utricle) are damaged by vestibulotoxic drugs like Streptomycin, Gentamicin, Tobramycin.

questions.text: The Government of India noticed a concerning trend of incomplete immunization coverage among children, leading to preventable diseases and health risks. In response, they launched a significant initiative to address this issue and ensure the complete immunization of children across the country. Which of the following initiatives was launched by the Government of India to achieve the objective of complete immunization of children?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mission Indradhanush

 

Mission Indradhanush was launched in 2014 by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to ensure complete immunization of children who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. Later, it was modified in 2017 as Intensified Mission Indradhanush to achieve the same goal by December 2018, including 12 vaccine-preventable diseases. The program involves 4 rounds of immunization held for 7 days each month, and it replaced the previous focus on 7 diseases.

 

 

The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are:

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Нерatitis B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are:

  • Rotavirus diarrhea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis

questions.text: A 65-year-old male experienced a stroke 48 hours ago, and he currently exhibits involuntary, forceful, and flinging movements of the limbs on one side of his body. Where is the probable location of the lesion in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Subthalamic nuclei

 

Most probable diagnosis as per the clinical history is hemiballismus which is caused by a lesion in subthalamic nuclei.

 

Hemiballismus is a disorder characterized by violent involuntary abnormal movements on one side of the body involving mostly the arm. While walking, the arm swings widely. These movements are called the flinging movements. These movements are due to the release phenomenon because of the absence of inhibitory influence on movements. Hemiballismus occurs due to degeneration of subthalamic nucleus of Luys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Globus pallidus is affected in Carbon monoxide poisoning and Wilson disease. Its degeneration leads to development of athetoid movements (slow writhing distal hand movements).

 

Option C) Putamen is the most common site of intracranial hypertensive bleed. Its degeneration leads to development of choreo-athetoid movements.

 

Option D) Caudate nucleus is located near the Thalamus. It is affected in Huntington disease and its degeneration leads to choreiform movements (involuntary purposeless jerky movements)

questions.text: The time required for preoxygenation before tracheal intubation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 3 min

 

Preoxygenation or denitrogenation is the process of replacing nitrogen in the lungs with oxygen.

 

It is done by giving 100% oxygen to the patient for 3 minutes through a tight-fitting mask or by asking him to take 8 vital capacity breaths.

 

This lengthened apnea time provides an improved margin of safety while the anaesthesiologist secures the airway and resumes ventilation.

 

There are two main methods commonly used for preoxygenation:

  1. The first method involves utilizing tidal volume ventilation through a face mask for a duration of 3 minutes. This technique allows for the exchange of approximately 95% of the gas present in the lungs.
  2. The second method relies on vital capacity breaths to achieve effective preoxygenation in a shorter time frame. While four breaths over 30 seconds are not as efficient as the tidal volume method, it may still be deemed acceptable in specific clinical scenarios. On the other hand, research has indicated that eight breaths over a span of 60 seconds are more effective for preoxygenation.

 

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1380

questions.text: A newborn is noted to have a continuous "machine-like" murmur heard best beneath the left clavicle. Which congenital heart defect should be suspected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)

 

A continuous "machine-like" murmur heard best beneath the left clavicle is indicative of a Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA). The PDA is a communication between the aorta and pulmonary artery that fails to close after birth. This results in continuous flow of blood from the aorta to the pulmonary artery throughout the cardiac cycle, causing the characteristic murmur.

 

The other options (A, C, and D) are not associated with a continuous murmur.

questions.text: Identical twins have similarities in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fingerprint pattern

 

Monozygotic twins (Identical twins) are conceived when a single egg fertilized by a single sperm split into two after fertilization. Such twins have 100% of their genes in common. Both of them invariably have the same blood type and are of the same sex.

 

Dizygotic twins (Fraternal twins) are conceived when two eggs are fertilized by two different sperms. They share 50% of their genes, just like any other siblings. Their blood types and sex can be either same or different.

 

So, all the inheritable characteristics will be exactly same in identical twins (e.g., Blood group, DNA fingerprinting, Iris Color).

 

But Fingerprints are not inheritable hence different even in identical twins. No finger-prints of 2 individuals are similar. It is 100% accurate method of identification.

questions.text:
Image Description: An MRI of an infant's brain showing periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) with areas of cystic necrosis.

 

Question: What is the most likely cause of the brain abnormalities seen in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hypoxic-Ischemic Encephalopathy (HIE)

 

The image demonstrates periventricular leukomalacia (PVL) with areas of cystic necrosis, which is a hallmark of Hypoxic-Ischemic Encephalopathy (HIE). HIE occurs due to insufficient oxygen and blood supply to the brain, often seen in neonates who experienced birth asphyxia or other complications leading to inadequate cerebral perfusion.

 

Meningitis, IVH, and Reye's Syndrome do not typically result in this specific pattern of brain damage.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female has presented to the OPD with the complaints of diplopia, drooping of the eyelids. Her HRCT was done which reveals a mediastinal mass. Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis of the patient is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Her symptoms of diplopia and drooping of eyelids are due to autoantibodies against Calcium channels

 

The clinical history of the patient (diplopia and drooping of eyelids with mediastinal mass) is suggestive of Myasthenia gravis due to Thymoma.

 

It is associated with reduced levels of immunoglobulins, also called as Good Syndrome.

 

Myasthenia gravis is a type II hypersensitivity disorder caused by antibodies that bind to the acetylcholine receptor. These antibodies interfere with the transmission of neural impulses at the neuromuscular junction, causing muscle weakness and easy fatigability. External ocular and eyelid muscles are most often affected, but the disease is often progressive and may cause death by respiratory muscle paralysis.

 

Antibodies to calcium channels are seen in Eaton-Lambert syndrome.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient has been diagnosed with hypertension. On examination, there is no existing cardiovascular disease, no hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD), and the renal function is normal. He should be immediately started on pharmacological management if his blood pressure is more than:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. > 160/100 mmHg

  • The ISH (International society of HTN) 2020 guidelines were made to help decision making in low-middle income countries.
  • Presence of ASCVD risk factors, HMOD (HTN mediated organ damage) is an indication to start anti-HTN therapy.
  • Home BP recording helps in diagnosis of Masked HTN, rule out white-coat effect.
  • ABPM provides 24-hour trend and fluctuations in BP.

Home BP > 135/85 mmHg = HTN

 

ABPM cutoffs:

  1. Mean Awake (daytime) average ≥ 135/85 mmHg
  2. 24h average ≥ 130/80 mmHg
  3. Mean Asleep(night) ≥ 120/70 mmHg

BP drops at night by (10-20%), morning surge – Steep increase, peaks in late afternoon.
 

Best observed in ABPM (Ambulatory BP monitoring):

  • Normal Dip: 10-20 % at night
  • Extreme Dip > 20%
  • Non-dippers < 10% (a/w Activation of RAAS)
  • Risers: BP raise

Note: Increase mortality risk among Non-Dippers and Risers.

 

 

Reference: ISH2020, AHA2017 HTN guidelines

questions.text: In the fracture shown in the X-ray below, what is the most commonly expected vascular injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Brachial artery

 

Supracondylar Fracture of the Humerus

  • This is one of the most serious fractures in childhood as it is often associated with complications.
  • It usually occurs in children aged 5-7 years.

Mechanism:

  • The fracture is caused by a fall on an out-stretched hand.
  • As the hand strikes the ground, the elbow is forced into hyperextension, resulting in fracture of the humerus above the condyles.

Pathoanatomy: The fracture line extends transversely through the distal metaphysis of humerus just above the condyles.

 

Types:

  • A supracondylar fracture may be of extension/flexion type, depending upon the displacement of the distal fragment.
  • The extension type is the commoner of the two where the distal fragment is extended (tilted backwards) in relation to the proximal fragment.
  • In the flexion type, the distal fragment is flexed (tilted forwards) in relation to the proximal fragment.
  • Gartland classification of extension type fractures:
    • Type I: Undisplaced/minimally displaced
    • Type II: Displaced but with intact cortex
    • Type III: Completely displaced

Complications:

  • Nerve injury: Anterior interosseous nerve most commonly injured followed by median, radial and ulnar nerves
  • Vessel injury: Brachial artery
  • Cubitus varus or gunstock deformity due to malunion

Cubitus varus or Gun stock deformity

questions.text: A 2 days old baby presents with tachypnoea, nasal flaring, grunting, and intercostal retractions. Chest X-ray reveals diffuse ground-glass opacities (white out lung) & hyperinflation. Which respiratory disorder is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS)

 

Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) is characterized by tachypnea, nasal flaring, grunting, and intercostal retractions in newborns. It is common in premature infants due to insufficient surfactant production, leading to increased surface tension in the alveoli. This results in collapsed alveoli and poor gas exchange. The chest X-ray findings of diffuse ground-glass opacities and hyperinflation are consistent with RDS.

 

While the other conditions can also cause respiratory symptoms, the clinical presentation and imaging findings point to RDS in this scenario.

Width of the base of the curve is directly proportional to the margin of error.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with a midline swelling in the neck. Upon examination, cervical node enlargement is also observed. Histopathological analysis of the lesion reveals the following. Which of the following statements is false regarding the same?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is not diagnostic.

 

The picture above depicts orphan Anne nuclei, and psammoma bodies. These findings are indicative of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid and can aid in its diagnosis.

  1. Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is the most common type of thyroid cancer, accounting for approximately 80% of all thyroid malignancies.
  2. It is typically slow-growing and has a high cure rate if detected early and properly treated.
  3. Papillary carcinoma arises from the follicular cells of the thyroid gland and is characterized by the presence of papillary structures when viewed under a microscope.
  4. Risk factors for developing papillary carcinoma of the thyroid include exposure to ionizing radiation and having a family history of thyroid cancer.
  5. Treatment for papillary carcinoma of the thyroid may include surgery, radioactive iodine therapy, and thyroid hormone replacement therapy.

choices.text: The Chaddah committee recommended establishing Primary Health Centers (PHC) at the block level to ensure better healthcare coverage in rural areas.
Another significant recommendation was to have one PHC available for every 50,000 population, which aimed to ensure adequate healthcare facilities in different regions.
Additionally, the committee proposed allocating one basic health worker for every 10,000 population, intending to address the healthcare needs of communities more effectively.
Assigning the responsibility of PHCs in malaria eradication as part of their proposed measures to enhance healthcare services.

questions.text: You are a healthcare professional reviewing the recommendations proposed by the Chaddah committee, a panel assigned by the government to improve healthcare services in the region. As you carefully examine their suggestions, please identify the recommendation that the committee did NOT include in their proposal:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Another significant recommendation was to have one PHC available for every 50,000 population, which aimed to ensure adequate healthcare facilities in different regions.

  • The Kartar Singh Committee and the Chaddah Committee were both established by the Government of India to provide recommendations for improving healthcare services in the country.
  • In 1973, the Kartar Singh Committee suggested that there should be one PHC for a population of 50,000, and each PHC should have at least one medical officer, one nurse, and three paramedical staff.
  • The Chaddah Committee, in 1963, recommended several measures to enhance healthcare services in rural areas, including the renaming of malaria workers and family planning workers as Basic Health Workers, the establishment of PHCs at the block level, assigning one BHW for every 10,000 people, and allocating the responsibility of malaria eradication to PHCs.

 

These recommendations have significantly impacted healthcare policy in India and contributed to the progress of the healthcare system in the country.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient has hypokalemia, hypertension and metabolic alkalosis. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Liddle’s Syndrome

 

 

Hypokalemia + HTN causes:

 

Aldosterone Activation

  • Liddle syndrome (ENaC channel Gain of function mutation)
  • Apparent Mineralocorticoid Excess (AME) (11Beta-HSD loss of function)
  • ↓11-βHSD→↑Cortisol →↑Stimulation of MR receptor → HTN + Hypokalemia + alkalosis
  • Geller Syndrome (Mineralocorticoid mutation responding to progesterone): Presents in pregnancy. Treatment with specific drug like Finerenone.
  • Glucocorticoid remediable Hyperaldosteronism (GRA): Chimeric gene b/w CYP11B1, B2 causing ACTH driven hyperaldosteronism.
  • Primary Hyperaldosteronism

Other options:

  • Option A - Bartter syndrome mimics loop diuretics which occur due to loss of function of Na+-K+-2Cl- transporter at the Loop of Henle. Often patient has NORMOTENSION.
  • Option C - Gitelman syndrome mimics thiazide diuretic occurring due to loss of function mutation of Na+-Cl- transporter in DCT.

    Both Bartter and Gitelman syndrome are normotensive
     
  • Option D - Gordon syndrome is opposite of Gitelman syndrome characterized by Gain of function mutation to Na+-Cl- channel which occurs either due to GOF of WNT1 pathway (OR) LOF of WNT 4 pathway, leads to inhibition of ROMK channel causing HYPERKALEMIA.

Note: Gordon = HTN + Hyperkalemia

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/ Physiology of Kidney/Chap 309 - Table 309-1

choices.text: The surgeon must use chromic catgut.
The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures.
The surgeon must use the single layer, extra-mucosal suture technique.
The surgeon must use the single- layer seromuscular suture technique.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with symptoms of an inguinal hernia. During the operation, the surgeon observes a segment of necrotic bowel in the hernial sac. What is the appropriate course of action for resection and anastomosis of a necrotic bowel seen during surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The surgeon must use the single layer, extra-mucosal suture technique.
 

Option A) The surgeon must use chromic catgut: Chromic catgut is a type of absorbable suture that is made from the collagen found in sheep or goat intestine. It is often used for intestinal anastomoses, as it is absorbable and does not require removal. However, chromic catgut has a relatively short duration of tensile strength, and so it is not recommended for use in areas of high tension or stress.

 

Option B) The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures: The submucosa is a layer of tissue beneath the mucosal lining of the bowel. It should be included in sutures as it is the toughest layer of the bowel.

 

Option C) The surgeon must use the single-layer, extramucosal suture technique: The single-layer, extramucosal suture technique involves using a single layer of sutures to join the two ends of the bowel together, while avoiding the mucosal layer. This technique is less time-consuming than the double-layer technique and reduces the risk of complications such as bleeding, stricture formation, and anastomotic leak.

 

Option D) The surgeon must use the single-layer seromuscular suture technique: The single-layer seromuscular suture technique involves suturing the seromuscular layer of the bowel to join the two ends together. This technique is quick and easy to perform but may not be suitable for all cases as it can increase the risk of anastomotic leakage and stenosis. Therefore, it is important to assess each case individually and choose the appropriate technique based on the specific circumstances.

questions.text: Multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses, demonstrating sulphur granules in pus, are caused by?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Actinomyces

  • Multiple abscesses with discharging sinuses, demonstrating sulfur granules in pus, are characteristic of actinomycosis caused by Actinomyces.
  • Actinomycosis is a chronic granulomatous infection characterized by indurated swellings mainly in the connective tissue with suppuration and discharge of sulfur granules.
  • Most common causative agent is Actinomyces israelli
  • Actinomycosis most commonly occurs as oral-cervicofacial form presenting as a soft tissue swelling, abscess, or mass lesion involving the angle of the jaw.

choices.text: Disaster impact - Mitigation - Rehabilitation - Response
Disaster impact - Response- Rehabilitation - Mitigation
Rehabilitation - Response - Disaster Impact - Mitigation
Response - Disaster impact - Mitigation - Rehabilitation

questions.text: Choose the correct order of steps of disaster management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Disaster impact - Response- Rehabilitation - Mitigation

 

The correct sequence of steps is disaster impact - response - rehabilitation - mitigation.

 

 

 

In Disaster Cycle, the steps involved are –

  1. Disaster Impact and Response: it involves search, rescue, first aid of the patients, triaging them according to the severity of their injuries and their likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention, tagging and identification of dead.
  2. Relief Phase or Disaster Containment by prompt assistance, epidemiological surveillance and disease control, vaccination, nutritional support.
  3. Rehabilitation involves restoration of the pre-disaster conditions. It takes into account assessment and restoration of water supply, food safety and supply, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, vector control.
  4. Disaster Mitigation involves measures aimed at reducing or preventing the hazards from causing any emergency or to dampen the effects of emergencies. It involves flood mitigation works, appropriate land-use planning, improved building codes and reduction or protection of vulnerable population and structures.
  5. Disaster Preparedness is a long-term programme of developmental activities which aims at strengthening the overall capacity and capability of the country to efficiently and effectively manage all the emergencies.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is indicated in management of Torsades de Pointes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Magnesium sulphate

 

Magnesium sulphate is given in the treatment of Torsades de pointes (QT prolongation).

 

Quinidine is a Class Ia anti arrhythmic drug that acts by blocking Na+ channels as well as K+ channels. It can lead to prolonged QT interval and Torsades’ de pointes.

 

Flecainide, Encainide and Propafenone are other drugs that belong to Class Ic antiarrhythmics and can also precipitate Torsades’ de pointes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Lignocaine is an ester local anaesthetic which belong to Class Ib anti-arrhythmic agents. It is the drug of choice in controlling digoxin-induced ventricular arrythmias and should not be used in Supra-ventricular arrythmia. Class Ib anti-arrhythmic agents are not known to cause QT prolongation.


Drugs causing Torsades de Pointes are –

  • Class 1c and 1a anti-arrhythmic agents, Sotalol, Amiodarone.
  • Levofloxacin, Ciprofloxacin, Gatifloxacin, Moxifloxacin
  • Clarithromycin, Erythromycin
  • Ketoconazole, Itraconazole
  • Haloperidol, Ziprasidone, Thioridazine
  • Tricyclic anti-depressants
  • Cisapride, Astemizole, Terfenadine

questions.text: A 45-year-old man from Bihar presents with fever, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly. Peripheral smear shown in image. What is the vector for the condition diagnosed by the image shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sandfly

  • The image shown is of the Leishman-Donovan bodies whose presence are diagnostic of Kala Azar.
  • The vector of Kala Azar is a sandfly.
  • Leishman-Donovan bodies are amastigotes with a double dot appearance containing a nucleus and small rodlike kinetoplast.
  • They are present inside the macrophage.

choices.text: Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles
Sulfur dioxide, lead, and particulate matter
Sulfur dioxide and carbon monoxide
Carbon monoxide and hydrogen sulfide

questions.text: In a bustling city with a rapidly growing population, concerns about air pollution have become increasingly prevalent. The local authorities have decided to implement routine monitoring of air quality to understand the extent of the problem and take appropriate measures to safeguard public health. Which of the following is the best indicators for routine monitoring of air pollution?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles

 

The best indicators for routine monitoring of air pollution are sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles.

 

Sulfur dioxide (SO2) is a common air pollutant that is produced by burning fossil fuels and industrial processes. It is a major contributor to acid rain and can cause respiratory problems in humans. Monitoring SO2 levels can help identify sources of pollution and evaluate the effectiveness of pollution control measures.

 

Smoke and suspended particles, such as particulate matter (PM), are also important indicators of air pollution. These particles can cause a range of health problems, including respiratory and cardiovascular diseases. Monitoring PM levels can help identify sources of pollution and evaluate the effectiveness of pollution control measures.

 

Lead and carbon monoxide (CO) are also common air pollutants, but they are not as useful as indicators for routine monitoring of air pollution. Lead is a toxic metal that can cause neurological problems in humans, but it is less commonly found in ambient air.

 

CO is a poisonous gas that is produced by incomplete combustion of fossil fuels, but it is not a good indicator for routine monitoring because it has a short half-life in the atmosphere and is not as persistent as other pollutants. Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) is a gas that has a strong odor and is associated with sewage treatment and other industrial processes, but it is not as commonly found in ambient air as other pollutants.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to ED with complaints of weakness, paresthesia, and breathing difficulty. Relevant investigations were done. The ECG obtained is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

 

History suggestive of cramps, muscle weakness is common in hypokalemia. ECG shows PR, QTc prolongation, T wave inversion, u waves. “NikEleKam T waves aka reverse wellen sign” seen in extreme Hypokalemia

 

ECG Findings in Hypokalemia:

  • U-waves
  • Prolonged QTc
  • Flattened/inverted Ts
  • Sagging ST
  • ST Depression
  • Biphasic t-waves
  • ST elevation in aVR
  • PVCs/Ventricular Dysrhythmias
  • Pseudo-ischemic patterns

choices.text: Site and area of injury
Mechanism of wound like laceration/crush

questions.text: Which of these is not a factor affecting wound healing?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Alcohol Addiction

 

Factors affecting wound healing:

  • Site - face, oral cavity (good healing)
  • Mechanism - incised (good) vs lacerated
  • Contamination - foreign body, bony spicules (poor)
  • Local factors - vascularity, previous radiation (poor), pressure points (poor)
  • Systemic factors - smoking, diabetes, steroids, immune deficiencies (poor)

choices.text: Maroteaux-Lamy disease
Hunter’s Disease
Hurler’s Disease

questions.text: A 2-year-old female child was brought by her parents with delayed developmental milestones and pain in lower limbs and difficulty in walking for 3 months. O/E: child had stiffness of joints in both upper and lower limbs and has coarse facial features, low IQ and hepatomegaly. Urinary examination: presence of heparan sulphate and dermatan sulphate; fibroblast study: Deficiency of enzyme iduronate-2-sulfatase. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hunter’s Disease.
 

Hunter Syndrome (Mucopolysaccharidosis Type II): Deficiency of iduronate sulfatase, Clinical Features – Mental Retardation, Skeletal deformity, deafness, no corneal clouding  with Dermatan Sulfate (DS) and Heparan Sulfate in urine.

 

 

Incorrect answers:

 

False: Option (a) Maroteaux-Lamy disease: Deficiency of N-Acetyl-β D Galactosamine- 4- Sulfatase, Clinical Features - Skeletal deformity, corneal opacity, No Mental Retardation and Dermatan Sulfate in urine.

 

False: Option (c) Hurler’s disease: is due to the deficiency of enzyme α-L Iduronidase causes accumulation of dermatan sulphate and heparan sulphate. Clinical Features: Mental retardation, coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, cloudy cornea

 

False: Option (d) Scheie’s disease: Deficiency of L-Iduronidase, Clinical features - No MR with mild skeletal changes, corneal opacity and DS in urine.

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 638-639, Nelson 20/e Tables 82.1 and 82.2

choices.text: After using Teriparatide the patient should be supplemented with bisphosphonates
Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year
Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day
Oral vitamin D3 is given along with oral calcium

questions.text: A 65-year-old postmenopausal female patient with a history of Colle's fracture presented with lower back pain. After assessment, Her T score was -2.5. Which of the following statements regarding the management of her condition is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year

 

This question deals with osteoporotic post-menopausal female, who has a history of fracture as well.

  • Bisphosphonates which act by inhibiting the bone resorption by the osteoclasts form the first line of treatment in this patient. Bisphosphonates are the DOC for Osteoporosis (Steroid induced, post-menopausal and due to any reason). These are indicated for 5 years and then a drug holiday of 2-3 years is given to avoid adverse effects (increased risk of bone fractures and osteonecrosis of mandible). These can be repeated for another 5 years after drug holiday.
  • Teriparatide is a PTH analog that helps in increasing the bone formation by increasing the osteoblastic activity. In this patient who has a history of osteoporotic fracture, Teriparatide can be given even before starting Bisphosphonates. However, teriparatide can be used for only 2 years.
  • Supplementation of Calcium at the rate of 1200 mg/day in elderly and Vitamin D with 800 IU/day also helps in improving the bone mineral density.

choices.text: Uptake of genetic material by other bacteria.

questions.text: Bacterial transduction occurs by?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Bacteriophage

 

Transduction is a process of acquiring bacterial DNA from a phage that has incorporated bacterial DNA from previous host bacteria (bacteriophage).

 

Other methods of exchange of genetic material are:

  • Transformation involves the uptake of genetic material from the environment, which is released by other bacteria.
  • Conjugation is the direct transfer of DNA from one bacterial cell to another bacterial cell through a sex pilus or bridge. The transferred DNA is a plasmid, a circle of DNA that is distinct from the main bacterial chromosome.
